questions.question: A middle-aged woman presents with flank pain and dysuria. The pain was temporarily relieved by intravenous analgesics administered at a nearby primary healthcare center. She is diagnosed with ureteric colic secondary to ureteric calculi. What is the most appropriate diagnostic modality in this case? B. IIIIIII D. III Ureteroscopy
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) NCCT KUB Explanation: Non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) is considered the gold standard for diagnosing renal stones. NCCT scans provide detailed images of the urinary tract and can identify both radiopaque (visible on X-rays) and radiolucent (not easily visible on X-rays) stones. Investigations for renal stones: Urinalysis This is often the initial investigation performed. It can reveal the presence of blood (hematuria), white blood cells (pyuria), and crystals in the urine, all suggestive of a possible stone. The pH of the urine can also give clues about the type of stone. Kidney, Ureter, and Bladder (KUB) X-ray It can detect some types of stones, particularly calcium-containing stones, which appear opaque on X-rays. Ultrasound (Option C ruled out) It's particularly useful for detecting hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidney due to urine blockage) caused by stones and can be helpful during pregnancy when minimising radiation exposure is important. Intravenous urogram (IVU) It involves injecting a contrast dye into a vein. The dye travels through the bloodstream to the kidneys, where it is filtered and excreted in the urine. X-rays are taken as the dye passes through the urinary tract, outlining the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. This test can reveal blockages in the urinary tract caused by stones. IIII (Option B) is usually not the first choice for stone detection because contrast can obscure small stones . It should be avoided in suspected acute renal colic cases unless there are other indications. Ureteroscopy (Option D) is invasive and typically performed as a therapeutic procedure to remove stones, not as a diagnostic tool. It is used when stone extraction or biopsy is required but not for routine diagnosis. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1467, 1475, 1469

questions.question: Identify the structure on prostate biopsy: C. III Amyloid
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Corpora amylacea Explanation: The laminated, round, basophilic bodies that can be seen in the prostate biopsy are Corpora amylacea. They are composed of proteinaceous material often found in the prostatic acini and ducts. They are believed to be precursors of prostatic calculi and are also commonly seen in BPH. Psammoma bodie s (Option A) are concentric, calcified structures commonly seen in certain tumours, like papillary thyroid carcinoma , serous ovarian carcinoma , or meningiomas . They are not typically associated with prostate tissue or prostate biopsies. Corpora arenacea (Option B), or brain sand , are calcified deposits in the pineal gland composed of calcium salts. They are a common and typically benign finding in the brain, particularly in older individuals. III Amyloid (Option D) deposits are abnormal proteins that can accumulate in tissues in various diseases, such as amyloidosis . While it can sometimes be seen in prostate tissue in rare conditions, it is not a common finding on prostate biopsy and is not associated with the structure described in this case.

questions.question: A newborn male presents with urinary retention, lethargy and a distended bladder. Antenatal ultrasound showed a "keyhole sign" with a thickened bladder wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer : C) Posterior urethral valves Explanation Posterior urethral valves are characterized by membranous folds in the posterior urethra leading to urinary obstruction, which matches the "keyhole sign" on ultrasound and the postnatal symptoms of urinary retention and lethargy. Posterior urethral valves Definition Urinary tract obstruction in male infants from membranous folds in the posterior urethra. Complications Chronic kidney disease, pulmonary hypoplasia from oligohydramnios. Classification Type I: Posterior urethral folds Type II: Membranes at bladder neck Type III: Round membrane at verumontanum Etiology Congenital, unclear embryological origin. Pathophysiology Increased bladder pressure → hypertrophy, vesicoureteric reflux, renal damage Diagnostic Tools Ultrasound, VCUG (voiding cystourethrogram) and Renal scintigraphy. Antenatal Diagnosis Ultrasound: Dilated bladder ("keyhole sign"), thickened walls. Postnatal Symptoms Urinary retention, infections, lethargy, respiratory distress. Management Antenatal: Vesicostomy, fetal valve ablation Postnatal: Stabilization, cystoscopic ablation Prognosis Depends on severity; long-term care needed for CKD, bladder dysfunction, recurrent UTIs. Hypospadias involves an abnormal urethral opening and does not present with the obstructive symptoms described, such as a distended bladder and urinary retention. (Option A) Vesicoureteral reflux can occur secondary to posterior urethral valves but is not the primary condition associated with the described ultrasound findings and symptoms. (Option B) Neurogenic bladder results from nerve damage affecting bladder function, but it is not typically associated with the "keyhole sign" seen in posterior urethral valves. (Option D) Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1538,1539 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560881/

questions.question: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a strong urge to urinate but is unable to do so. He has a history of perineal trauma. On examination, blood is noted at the external urethral meatus. Which structure is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: void → Suggests urethral obstruction . History of perineal injury → Strongly suggests trauma to the anterior urethra . Blood at the meatus → A classic sign of urethral injury . Bulbar urethral injury is common in perineal trauma : Common mechanism : Straddle injuries (e.g., fall on a hard surface). Bulbar urethra is vulnerable due to its location in the anterior urethra. Extravasation of urine may be seen if severe. Urethral Injuries Urethral Segment Common Causes of Injury Clinical Features Bulbar urethra (Anterior) Straddle injuries, blunt perineal trauma Blood at meatus, urinary retention, perineal hematoma Membranous urethra (Posterior) Pelvic fractures High-riding prostate, inability to pass urine Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture Blunt abdominal trauma Peritonitis, urinary ascites Posterior Urethral Valve Congenital anomaly Recurrent UTIs, voiding difficulty Posterior urethral valve (Option B): Incorrect because it is a congenital condition seen in infants, not in a previously healthy young adult. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture (Option C): Incorrect because it presents with peritonitis and urinary ascites , not blood at the meatus or perineal trauma. Membranous urethra (Option D): Incorrect because it is typically injured in pelvic fractures , which are not mentioned in the history. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1541,1542. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 1767. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 1040-1042.

questions.question: A child presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a radiological image as given. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.explanation: valves presents to the outpatient department (OPD). The most appropriate management for this condition is endoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using a cystoscope to remove or ablate the obstructive valve tissue, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urine flow. Incorrect Options: Option B - Dilation of urethra: Dilation involves stretching the urethra to relieve obstruction. However, this is not suitable for treating PUV because the obstruction is caused by a valve rather than a stenotic segment. Dilation does not address the underlying problem of the valve. Option C - Dilation of urethra and bladder: While dilation of the urethra might alleviate some symptoms, it does not address the underlying issue of PUV. Additionally, bladder dilation is not a standard treatment for PUV and does not effectively manage the obstruction. Option D - Conservative: Conservative management may include monitoring and supportive care, but it does not resolve the obstruction caused by PUV. This approach is not adequate for managing the condition, as it fails to address the cause of the urinary obstruction. Reference: .

questions.question: A young patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with recurrent colicky abdominal pain. Urine examination reveals the presence of red blood cells (RBCs). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: along with RBCs, strongly suggests cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to the formation of cystine stones. These stones are rare and are caused by the poor reabsorption of cystine in the kidneys, leading to its crystallization in urine. The recurrent colicky abdominal pain is typical of urolithiasis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Glomerulonephritis: This condition involves inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys and typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria, and sometimes RBC casts, but not with benzene-shaped crystals. Option B - Oxalate stone: Calcium oxalate stones are common and may present with similar symptoms, but they are characterized by envelope-shaped crystals in the urine, not benzene-shaped crystals. Option C - Polycystic kidney disease: This genetic disorder leads to the development of multiple cysts in the kidneys and can cause hematuria, hypertension, and renal failure. However, it does not cause the formation of benzene-shaped crystals in the urine. Reference: .

questions.question: A 12-year-old child presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a complaint of scrotal pain, with a history of trauma 6 hours prior. Upon surgical exploration, the findings suggest significant damage. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: Torsion of testicular appendages with gangrene

questions.explanation: cord twists, cutting off the blood supply to the testicle. If untreated for several hours, this can lead to gangrene due to ischemia. The history of trauma and rapid onset of pain, along with surgical findings, strongly suggest testicular torsion with gangrene. Incorrect Options: Option B - Torsion of testicular appendages with gangrene: Torsion of testicular appendages, such as the appendix testis, is less common and usually presents with localized pain. While it can cause significant discomfort, it typically does not lead to the severe ischemia and gangrene seen in testicular torsion. Blue dot sign: torsion of appendage of testis Option C - Gangrene: Gangrene refers to tissue death due to loss of blood supply. In this context, the term alone is nonspecific, and without the identification of an underlying cause, such as testicular torsion, it does not fully describe the condition. Option D - Hematoma: A hematoma can occur due to trauma, leading to localized swelling and pain. However, it would not typically present with the severe ischemic changes seen in testicular torsion unless associated with vascular injury.

questions.question: What instrument is used to insert this tube?
questions.explanation: the urinary tract. It is used to visualize the bladder and urethra through the urethra, allowing for the insertion of various tubes or instruments for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Nephroscope: This instrument is specifically used to visualize and treat conditions within the kidney. It is typically employed for procedures such as percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) to remove kidney stones. It is not used for inserting tubes into the urinary tract. Option C - Ureteroscope : This instrument is used to visualize and treat conditions within the ureters (the tubes connecting the kidneys to the bladder). It is used for procedures such as ureteroscopy to remove stones or diagnose issues in the ureters, but not typically for inserting a tube into the urinary tract. Option D - Endoscope: While endoscopes are used for visualizing internal body structures, they are not specific to the urinary tract. The term "endoscope" encompasses a wide range of instruments used for various types of internal examination, including but not limited to cystoscopes, colonoscopes, and bronchoscopes.

questions.question: A patient was brought to the emergency department with a history of fall and head injury. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: isodense lesion on a CT scan, located between the dura mater and the brain's surface. It is commonly associated with bridging vein rupture, often seen in cases of trauma or in the elderly. It often has a more diffuse and irregular boundary compared to EDH. Incorrect Options: Option A - Epidural Hematoma (EDH): Typically appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on a CT scan, located between the dura mater and the skull. It is usually associated with a skull fracture and tends to have a more well-defined boundary. It occurs due to rupture of the meningeal arteries. Option C - Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Typically appears as hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain on a CT scan. It is often diffuse and can be seen around the sulci and ventricles. It usually occurs due to the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Option D - Contusion: Appears as localized areas of hemorrhage within the brain tissue itself. On a CT scan, it often shows as areas of mixed density with associated edema, and it is typically more focal rather than diffuse or crescent-shaped.

questions.question: Identify the procedure done.
questions.explanation: entire penis. It is typically performed in cases of penile cancer or severe trauma. Incorrect Options: Option A - Orchidectomy: This procedure involves the surgical removal of one or both testicles for testicular carcinoma, not penile cancer. Option C - Partial Penectomy: This procedure involves the surgical removal of part of the penis. It is usually done for localized penile cancer, where only a portion of the penis is affected.

questions.question: A patient presents with a growth over the penis that is classified as a T3 lesion, with no enlarged inguinal lymph nodes detected. What is the best method of management?

options.C: Penectomy with superficial/inguinal lymph node dissection(MODIFIED)
options.D: Penectomy with deep inguinal lymph node dissection

questions.explanation: involves removing the penis and performing a dissection of the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. It is done in cases of T3 lesion of tumor but no enlarged or visible lymph nodes as Elective prophylactic lymph node dissection.If superficial lymph nodes becomes positive ,then must go for deep inguinal lymph nodes dissection. Incorrect Options: Option D - Penectomy with Deep Inguinal Lymph Node Dissection: This approach is done with nodal positive cases as Therapeutic lymph node dissection.In this case 1st superficial lymph nodes must be dissected ,if becomes positive go for deep inguinal lymph nodes dissection. Option A - Penectomy: This procedure involves the surgical removal of the penis. While it addresses the primary tumor, it does not account for potential metastasis to the lymph nodes, which is critical in the management of penile cancer, especially with a T3 lesion indicating a more advanced stage. Option B - Penectomy with Orchidectomy: This involves the removal of the penis along with the testicles. Orchidectomy is sometimes performed if there is a suspicion of testicular involvement or if the cancer is considered to be related to testicular issues. However, in the absence of evidence of testicular involvement or enlarged lymph nodes, this approach might be excessive and does not specifically address potential regional lymph node metastasis. . Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1055,1056

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On evaluation, malignancy is suspected, and an orchidectomy is performed. The gross section of the testicular mass is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Seminoma Explanation: The gross section of the testicular mass shows a homogeneous, grey-white appearance without necrosis or hemorrhage, suggesting Seminoma, which is the most common testicular tumour. Seminoma Feature Details Tumor Type Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumour in men aged 25-45 Origin Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules Clinical Features Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia Diagnostic Markers AFP: Normal hCG: Normal or mildly elevated LDH: Elevated Investigation Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli FNAC: Contraindicated due to risk of tumor cell seeding and lymph node metastasis Treatment Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy

questions.question: An adult male presents to the outpatient department with a painful scrotal swelling accompanied by fever. The swelling is associated with the tunica vaginalis and is characterized by fluid accumulation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hydrocele Explanation: A hydrocele is characterized by the buildup of fluid within the tunica vaginalis, the protective membrane surrounding the testis. This condition can cause scrotal swelling, which may be painful or uncomfortable and occasionally accompanied by fever. Hydrocele: Collection of fluid between the two layers of the tunica vaginalis of the testis Aetiology Defective absorption of fluid by tunica vaginalis due to endothelial wall damage by low-grade infection Excessive production of fluid (secondary hydrocele) Interference with drainage of fluid by lymphatic vessels of the cord Communication with the peritoneal cavity Primary Vaginal Hydrocele Common in middle-aged men, prevalent in tropical countries Testis is usually large and non-palpable Fluctuant Can get above the swelling Initially transilluminant, but becomes non-transilluminant if long-standing Infantile Hydrocele Tunica and processus vaginalis distended up to the internal ring No connection with the peritoneal cavity Congenital Hydrocele Processus vaginalis communicates with the peritoneal cavity Fluid disappears when lying down and recollects when standing Encysted Hydrocele of the Cord Fluid collection in a portion of the patent funicular process of tunica vaginalis Fluctuant and transilluminant Located in the inguinal/inguinoscrotal/scrotal part Secondary Vaginal Hydrocele Causes: Infection (filariasis, tuberculosis), injury (trauma, post herniorrhaphy), tumor (malignancy) Usually small, lax, and testis is palpable except in cases of filariasis where it can be very large Surgical Procedure Lord's plication - small, thin hydrocele with clear fluid Jaboulay's operation - partial sac removal and eversion Incorrect Options: Varicocele (Option A) involves dilation of the pampiniform plexus of veins and typically presents as a soft, irregular mass that may feel like a "bag of worms." It is usually asymptomatic, though it can sometimes cause pain or infertility. Cystocele (Option C) refers to the prolapse of the bladder into the vaginal canal and is not related to scrotal swelling. Torsion testis (Option D) is a surgical emergency caused by twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to compromised blood flow to the testis. It typically presents with acute, severe pain and swelling but does not usually involve fluid accumulation in the tunica vaginalis. The swelling is often more tender and associated with an absence of the cremasteric reflex. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1057-1060

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia. Ultrasound reveals a 1 cm solid mass within the body of the testis. Serum testosterone is 600 ng/dL, and estradiol is 35 pg/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Leydig cell tumor Explanation: Leydig cell tumors are the most likely diagnosis in this case. These tumors often present with gynecomastia due to the production of estrogens, as they secrete both testosterone and estrogen. The patient's elevated serum sex hormones suggests Leydig cell tumors. Sex cord-stromal tumours have two major subtypes: Leydig cell and Sertoli cell tumour. Leydig cell tumour Sertoli cell tumour Hormonal involvement It often involves androgens, oestrogens, and corticosteroids. Hormonally silent. Conditions associated with Klinefelter syndrome. Cryptorchidism. Renal cell carcinoma. Carney complex. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Familial adenomatous polyposis. Malignancy 10% (in adults) 10% Gross Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter. They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces. Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous grey-white to yellow cut surface. Histology The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts. They are large in size and have round or polygonal cell outlines , abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm , and a round central nucleus. The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets , vacuoles , or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumours). The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules. Image Incorrect Options: Spermatocytic tumors (Option A) are typically benign and present with a painless testicular mass. They are usually diagnosed in older men (over 50 years of age) and are characterised by a slow-growing mass & do not secrete any hormones. Sertoli cell tumours (Option B) mostly present as painless testicular masses. They are hormonally silent but sometimes produce estrogen & are less commonly associated with elevated estradiol levels compared to Leydig cell tumors. The presence of gynaecomastia along with increased testosterone makes Leydig cell tumour more likely. Granulosa cell tumours (Option C) are more commonly seen in females and are extremely rare in males. They usually present as slow-growing and non-functioning testicular mass.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain. A CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT) abdomen was done. What is the likely source of pain?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Kidney Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in this case, given the irregular enhancement and enlargement of the renal lesion on CECT, is Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC), making the origin of pain the kidney most likely. Clinical Features of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC): Classic symptoms such as hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable abdominal mass - “ TOO - LATE” TRIAD seen in 10% of patients with advanced disease. Systemic symptoms like weight loss, fever, and fatigue can also occur. In advanced stages, RCC may metastasise to the lungs, bones, and brain. A non-reducing varicocele, referred to as a suspicious varicocele , may indicate the presence of renal cell carcinoma (RCC), often due to a thrombus originating from the left RCC. Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant. Surgical Management: Partial Nephrectomy (Option A): Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney. Indications: T1 Disease(<7cm) Restricted to poles RCC in solitary functioning kidney Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim. Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible Ablative Techniques Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures. Indications: Patients who are not surgical candidates Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm). Systemic Therapy (For advanced/ metastatic disease) Targeted Therapy Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib) mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus) Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab) Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20th Edition, Page 2091, 2092 Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1482

questions.question: All of the following statements regarding Wilms tumor are true, except?

options.C: Majority patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
options.D: Lung involvement in uncommon and occurs late

questions.explanation: recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy is a wrong statement. Wilm's tumor still has a poor prognosis in developing countries, comparatively. The treatment of choice in Wilms tumor is radical nephrectomy. Chemotherapy and radiotherapy is started only if the histological prognostic factors following radical nephrectomy are poor. Incorrect Options: Option A - Presents as an abdominal mass: Wilms tumor presents with triad of intra-abdominal mass, fever, and hematuria. Option B - Most commonly seen <5yrs of age: Wilms tumor is the most common primary renal malignancy of childhood, usually seen among children of 2-5 years of age. Option D - Lung involvement in uncommon and occurs late: Lung involvement in Wilms tumor is around 10% and it occurs late. Reference: .

questions.question: 45-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of right flank pain, hematuria, and a history of urinary tract infections. Urine analysis shows alkaline urine with a pH of 8.0. Microscopy revealed the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: microscopy which is diagnostic of Struvite stones. Struvite stones are also known as staghorn calculi/ Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4 + , phosphate). These stones are most common in females because of short urethra (4 cm). Short urethra increases the risk of UTI by Proteus which produces urease. Urease converts urea into ammonia and ammonia gets precipitated. Struvite stone is very large & fills the pelvicalyceal system and looks like staghorn (due to branching in stone) → very large silent destruction of the kidney. Incorrect Options: Option B - Ca Oxalate Stones: Ca Oxalate monohydrate Stones are dumbbell shaped and Ca Oxalate dihydrate Stones are envelope shaped. Option C - Uric Acid Stones: Uric Acid Stones are rosette shaped and multi-faceted. Option D - Cystine Stones: Cystine Stones are hexagonal or benzene shaped.

questions.question: Identify the condition in the image:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bulbar urethral stricture Explanation: The image shows a micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) , which reveals a bulbar urethral stricture . The most common cause of urethral stricture is trauma , often due to external forces like an external blow , kick , or straddle injuries (e.g., falling onto a hard object like a manhole). Bulbar urethral injury falls under anterior urethral injury , and retrograde urethrogram (RGU) is the investigation of choice for such injuries. However, both RGU and MCU are often performed in emergency cases. Male Urethra: Fibromuscular tube extending from the bladder neck to the meatus and functions to transport urine and semen. Posterior urethra: Prostatic urethra and membranous urethra. Anterior urethra : Bulbar urethra, Penile urethra, and Urethral meatus. Urethral Meatus : Vertical slit-like opening at the tip of the glans penis. Glandular Urethra, also known as the fossa navicularis. Penile Urethra : Extends from the meatus to the penoscrotal junction. The longest part of the urethra Bulbar Urethra : Extends from the penoscrotal junction to the bulbomembranous junction. Membranous Urethra : Extends from the bulbomembranous junction to the verumontanum. The shortest, narrowest, and least dilated part is innervated by the pudendal nerve from spinal segments S2-4. Prostatic Urethra : Extends from the bladder neck to the verumontanum and is surrounded by the prostate. The widest and most dilatable part of the urethra. Feature Anterior Urethral Injury Posterior Urethral Injury Location Bulbar urethra (most common) Penile urethra Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common) Prostatic urethra Common Causes Straddle injuries Direct trauma Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy) Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds) Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents) Blunt trauma Clinical Features Hematuria (blood in urine) Penile/perineal bruising

questions.question: A patient develops a severe infection and necrosis in the scrotal region after 5 days of catheterization. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Fournier’s gangrene Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests Fournier's gangrene , a severe soft tissue infection involving the perineum. This condition is typically caused by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection . This condition is characterised by a mixed infection involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. The most common aerobic microorganisms include Escherichia coli, Proteus, Staphylococcus, Klebsiella, and Streptococcus. The predominant anaerobic microorganisms are Bacteroides, Clostridium, and Peptostreptococcus. Fournier's Gangrene Definition Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis. Clinical Presentation Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases: Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy. Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus. Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema. Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation. Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge. Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses. Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock. Risk Factors Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states. Diagnosis Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings. Management Initial Treatment: Fluid resuscitation. Broad-spectrum antibiotics. Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. Additional Measures: Urinary and faecal diversion to prevent wound contamination. Intensive monitoring for sepsis. Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing. Skin grafting post-infection control. Incorrect Options: Gas gangrene (Option B) i s a severe infectious condition caused by

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a painless testicular mass. After orchidectomy, histopathological examination reveals the presence of Reinke's crystals within the tumor cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Leydig cell tumor Explanation: Reinke's Crystals are typically seen in Leydig cell tumors, which is a type of sex cord-stromal tumor. Sexcord stromal tumors: Leydig cell tumour Sertoli cell tumor (Option A ruled out) Hormonal involvement It often involves androgens, estrogens, and corticosteroids. Hormonally silent. Conditions associated with Klinefelter syndrome. Cryptorchidism. Renal cell carcinoma. Carney complex. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Familial adenomatous polyposis. Malignancy 10% (in adults) 10% Gross Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter. They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces. Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous grey-white to yellow cut surface. Histology The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts. They are large and have round or polygonal cell outlines , abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm , and a round central nucleus. The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets , vacuoles , or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumors). The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules. Image Seminoma: (Option C ruled out) Reinke's Crystals are not present in seminomas. Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour, typically seen in the 3rd and 4th decades of life. Tumor markers associated with seminomas include beta-HCG, which is commonly elevated, along with markers related to disease bulk, such as: LDH PLAP GGT Yolk sac tumor: (Option D ruled out) The tumor marker for yolk sac tumors is alpha-fetoprotein. Yolk sac tumors are the most common testicular tumors in children, particularly between 1-3 years of age. Yolk sac tumors are also associated with the best prognosis among testicular tumors.

questions.question: Post-orchidectomy, the specimen shows Reinke's Crystals. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Leydig Cell Tumor Explanation: Reinke's Crystals are typically seen in Leydig cell tumours, which is a type of sex cord-stromal tumour. Sexcord stromal tumors: Leydig cell tumour Sertoli cell tumour Hormonal involvement It often involves androgens, oestrogens, and corticosteroids. Hormonally silent. Conditions associated with Klinefelter syndrome. Cryptorchidism. Renal cell carcinoma. Carney complex. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Familial adenomatous polyposis. Malignancy 10% (in adults) 10% Gross Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter. They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces. Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous grey-white to yellow cut surface. Histology The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts. They are large in size and have round or polygonal cell outlines , abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm , and a round central nucleus. The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets , vacuoles , or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumours). The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules. Image Seminoma: (Option A) Reinke's Crystals are not present in seminomas. Seminoma is the most common testicular tumour, typically seen in the 3rd and 4th decades of life. Tumor markers associated with seminomas include beta-HCG, which is commonly elevated, along with markers related to disease bulk, such as: LDH PLAP GGT Metastasis (Option C): Reinke's Crystals are not found in metastatic testicular disease. Yolk sac tumor: (Option D) The tumour marker for yolk sac tumours is alpha-fetoprotein. Yolk sac tumours are the most common testicular tumours in children, particularly between 1-3 years of age. Yolk sac tumours are also associated with the best prognosis among testicular tumours.

questions.question: A 45 year old patient with a history of kidney stones that were surgically removed 2 years ago presents with complaints of fever and flank pain. Imaging done is shown here. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation: bladder. Cystoscopy is a minimally invasive procedure that involves inserting a thin tube with a camera (cystoscope) into the urinary tract to visualize and potentially remove foreign bodies or stones. This option seems reasonable if the imaging has revealed the presence of a foreign body in the urinary tract and it's contributing to the patient's symptoms. Cystoscopic retrieval is a less invasive approach compared to open surgery. Incorrect Options: Option A - Laparotomy to remove the stones: Laparotomy involves making a surgical incision in the abdominal wall to access the internal organs. It is generally not the first-line approach for kidney stone removal. Kidney stones can often be managed through less invasive methods such as lithotripsy or endoscopic procedures.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male patient presents with urinary complaints. He has a history of working in a dye factory in the past. On USG examination, his bladder walls are found to be thickened and irregular. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: bladder. This option is the most appropriate choice based on the patient's history of working in a dye factory, urinary complaints, and findings of thickened and irregular bladder walls. Exposure to certain chemicals, such as those used in dye factories, can increase the risk of bladder cancer. The presentation suggests a potential malignancy, and radical cystectomy is a definitive treatment for invasive bladder cancer that hasn't responded to more conservative treatments. It involves removing the bladder along with nearby lymph nodes and, in some cases, other adjacent organs. This procedure is reserved for cases where the cancer has invaded the bladder wall or has a high likelihood of spreading. Incorrect Options: Option A - Instillation of BCG: Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) instillation is a treatment commonly used for superficial bladder cancer and not for urinary complaints related to thickened and irregular bladder walls. BCG is a type of immunotherapy that helps stimulate the immune system to fight cancer cells. It is not appropriate for this patient's presentation. Option B - Cystoscopy with Tumor Removal: While cystoscopy with tumor removal is indicated for patients with bladder tumors or suspected bladder cancer, this patient's presentation of urinary complaints, thickened, and irregular bladder walls is not indicative of a tumor. Therefore, this option is not the most appropriate management for this patient. Option C - Intravesical Mitomycin C: Intravesical mitomycin C is a treatment option for superficial bladder cancer, similar to BCG

questions.question: What is the best investigation to assess renal perfusion?
questions.explanation: involves injecting a radioactive tracer (DTPA) into the bloodstream. The tracer is taken up by the kidneys and then its distribution and clearance are monitored using gamma camera imaging. This allows for the assessment of renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and overall renal perfusion. It is particularly useful in diagnosing conditions like renal artery stenosis or renal vascular disorders that affect renal perfusion. Incorrect options: Option B - DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan: DMSA scan is used to assess the functioning of the renal parenchyma. It is used to diagnose or monitor kidney infections and scarring. Option C - RGU (retrograde urethrogram): RGU is an imaging test used to visualize the urethra and the urinary bladder. Option D - CT urogram: CT urogram is a radiological examination that involves the use of a contrast dye to visualize the urinary tract structures, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. It is more focused on detecting structural abnormalities.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a painless mass in the abdomen. Upon examination, a large mobile abdominal mass is noted, and it does not cross the midline. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: tumor in children. It often presents as an asymptomatic abdominal mass, and the classic presentation includes a large, non-tender, and mobile mass that does not cross the midline. Wilm's tumor is typically found in children aged 3 to 4 years. Incorrect Options: Option A - Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is another childhood cancer, but it typically arises in the adrenal glands and may present as an abdominal mass. However, the characteristic presentation for neuroblastoma is not restricted to the kidneys, and it may cross the midline. Option B - Angiomyolipoma: Angiomyolipoma’s are more commonly seen in the kidneys in adults and are associated with tuberous sclerosis. This is less likely in a 4-year-old child. Option C - Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma is extremely rare in children, and the typical age of onset is much later in adulthood.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of dysuria and intermittent back pain. On examination, there are no palpable abdominal masses or tenderness. An X-ray image of the abdomen is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) PTH adenoma Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is PTH adenoma . Parathyroid hormone (PTH) adenoma can cause hypercalcemia , which may lead to symptoms like dysuria and back pain. Radiologically, PTH adenoma may cause characteristic findings, such as kidney stones or calcifications due to calcium imbalance. Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism : The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma ( most common on the inferior lobe of the right parathyroid). Double adenomas are rare (2-4%). Parathyroid hyperplasia: enlargement of all 4 glands. Parathyroid carcinoma Manifestations of PHPT: System Manifestations Reason Renal system (stones) Hypercalciuria Nephrocalcinosis Nephrolithiasis Polydipsia, polyuria, nocturia Excretion of excess serum calcium Calcium deposition in renal parenchyma Precipitation of calcium with phosphate or oxalate Inhibition of ADH due to ↑

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presented with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis. Examination reveals that the inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Partial penectomy Explanation: Partial penectomy is the management of localised tumors on the glans penis. Management of Penile carcinoma: Cancer Type/Stage Management Localized Tumor - Glans Only Partial penectomy Distal Penile Involvement Partial penectomy with 2cm margin Proximal Penile Involvement /Anaplastic Tumors Total penectomy with perineal urethrostomy Carcinoma in situ, T1 Lesions, Well-Differentiated Tumors in Young Circumcision followed by curative radiotherapy Inguinal Lymph Node Involvement Bilateral ilioinguinal lymph node dissection Advanced Disease - T2 or Poorly Differentiated Tumors Prophylactic inguinal nodal dissection Carcinoma in situ Topical treatments ( 5-FU cream , imiquimod), Mohs surgery, laser therapy , or limited excision Chemotherapy Combination chemotherapy (5-FU, methotrexate, bleomycin, cisplatin, vincristine) TNM staging of penile cancer AJCC 8th edition, 2018: Stage Description TX Primary tumours cannot be assessed T0 No evidence of a primary tumour Tis Carcinoma in situ (Penile intraepithelial neoplasia, PeIN) Ta Noninvasive localised squamous cell carcinoma T1 Tumor invades lamina propria, dermis, or connective tissue with/without lymphovascular or perineural invasion T1a: without invasion/high grade T1b: with invasion/high grade T2 Tumor invades corpus spongiosum with or without urethral invasion T3 Tumor invades corpora cavernosa with or without urethral invasion T4 Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., prostate, scrotum, pubic bone) cNX Regional nodes cannot be assessed cN0 No palpable or visible enlarged inguinal nodes cN1 Palpable mobile unilateral inguinal lymph node cN2 Palpable mobile unilateral ≥ 2 inguinal lymph nodes cN3 Palpable fixed inguinal nodal mass or pelvic lymphadenopathy (unilateral or bilateral) cM0 No distant metastases cM1 Distant metastases pM1 Distant metastasis microscopically confirmed Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1053-1055

questions.question: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and necrotic tissue, as seen in the image, are noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?

options.A: Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases
options.B: Urinary diversion is the next step
options.C: A bilateral orchidectomy must be done

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests Fournier's gangrene , a severe soft tissue infection involving the perineum. This condition is typically caused by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection . The most common aerobic microorganisms include Escherichia coli , Proteus , Staphylococcus , Klebsiella , and Streptococcus . The predominant anaerobic microorganisms are Bacteroides , Clostridium , and Peptostreptococcus . Fournier's Gangrene Definition Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis. Clinical Presentation Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases: Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy. Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus. Progressive Phase: Increased pain and erythema. Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation. Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge. Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses. Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock. Risk Factors Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism,

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the provided medical condition? β -hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial

options.A: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
options.B: This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
options.D: Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition Explanation: The image shows Meleney’s gangrene. Hyperbaric oxygen is actually beneficial in the management of Meleney's gangrene, as it helps to improve oxygen delivery to tissues, inhibit bacterial growth, and promote wound healing. Necrotizing Fasciitis and Related Conditions: Meleney’s Synergistic Gangrene and Fournier’s Gangrene are variants of a similar disease process. Necrotising fasciitis is caused by a synergistic polymicrobial infection , most commonly involving Group A β -hemolytic Streptococcus combined with other bacteria such as Staphylococcus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas, Proteus, Bacteroides, or Clostridium. 80% of cases are linked to a history of previous trauma or infection. Common locations : Lower extremities in over 60% of cases. Predisposing conditions include: Diabetes mellitus Smoking Penetrating trauma (e.g., bites, abrasions) Pressure sores Immunosuppression Intravenous drug abuse Perineal infections (e.g., perianal abscess, Bartholin’s cyst) Skin

questions.question: A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in the left kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Renal angiomyolipoma Explanation: The presence of hematuria and a neovascular mass in the left kidney on a CT scan suggests a benign renal tumor, likely Renal Angiomyolipoma (AML) . Arise from Perivascular epithelioid cells Types Sporadic AMLs: Present in the 4th-6th decades, typically small, solitary, and slow-growing. TSC-associated AMLs: Present earlier (3rd-4th decades), larger, multiple, bilateral, and tend to grow. Symptoms Abdominal or flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, anemia. Impaired kidney function, usually due to hemorrhage (severe complication). Wunderlich syndrome : Nontraumatic kidney hemorrhage. Risk Factors for AML Complications Pregnancy: Increased risk of hemorrhage TSC-associated AMLs: Higher risk of CKD and ESKD Epithelioid AMLs: Potential for malignant transformation, metastasis, and local recurrence. Risk factors for hemorrhage: AML size (>6 cm) Increased vascularity Large intralesional aneurysms (>5 mm) Exophytic growth pattern. Histology Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures. Diagnosis CT: (Investigation of choice) Presence of intralesional fat and neovascular mass. USG: Appears as hyperechoic Immunocytochemical analysis: Differentiates AML from RCC, using markers like HMB-45 and melan-A . Treatment Observation (tumors <4 cm) Nephron-Sparing Surgery(Partial nephrectomy) (larger tumors or those with a high risk of bleeding) Angioembolization (acute hemorrhage). Medications (mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and sirolimus). Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) (Option A) is a malignant tumor of the kidney that appears as a solid, heterogeneous mass with irregular borders and necrosis. While it shows neovascularization, it lacks the fat component and distinct vascular pattern of angiomyolipomas (AMLs). The presence of these benign features suggests AML, not RCC. Renal

questions.question: Which lymph node is most commonly involved in prostate cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pelvic Explanation: Prostate Cancer primarily spreads to regional pelvic lymph nodes, including the external and internal iliac nodes, before metastasizing to other areas. Most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years. Most common among Afro-American Risk factor Advanced age High-fat diet Protective factors (Mnemonic: LESA) L ycopene Vitamin E S elenium Vitamin A Pathology Most common site- peripheral zone (75%) > transitional zone (15%) > central zone (10%) Most common histological type is adenocarcinoma Most common genetic alteration seen in CA prostate- hypermethylation of GSTP1 (Glutathione transferase promoter region 1) located on chromosome 11. 70-80% of the cases. Microscopy: small, crowded, absent basal layer, lack of branching Clinical features Commonly asymptomatic. Bladder outlet obstruction. Haematuria Pelvic pain, back pain, arthritic pain in sacroiliac joint-features of secondaries On per rectal examination: hard, nodular, irregular often with loss of median groove. Routes of spread Most common route of spread- haematogenous (skeletal metastases: pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae) Lymphatic: Internal iliac, external iliac lymph nodes, retroperitoneal lymph nodes, mediastinal nodes and occasionally the supraclavicular nodes. Investigations DRE (Digital Rectal Exam): Physical examination; detects nodules but limited in early-stage PSA (prostate-specific antigen) Test: Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer TRUS (Transrectal Ultrasound): Imaging with rectal probe; detects abnormalities mpMRI (Multiparametric MRI): Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread Prostate Biopsy: Gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells Management Active Surveillance: For low-risk cases; regular monitoring Radical Prostatectomy: Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative Radiation Therapy: High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy Hormone Therapy: Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases Chemotherapy: Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1531-1533. SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1037-1039.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?

options.A: Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism Explanation: The given image depicts Fournier's Gangrene , which results from a polymicrobial infection involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, rather than solely Staphylococcus aureus Fournier's Gangrene Definition Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis. Causative Organisms Mixed infection of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria in a fulminating inflammation of the subcutaneous tissues. (Option A) Clinical Presentation Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases: Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy. Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus. Progressive Phase: Increased pain, erythema. Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation. Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge. Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses. Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock. Risk Factors Peripheral vascular disease Diabetes mellitus (Option B ruled out) Malnutrition Alcoholism Immunocompromised states. Diagnosis Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings. Management Initial Treatment: Fluid resuscitation. Broad-spectrum antibiotics. Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. Additional Measures: Daily rounds (high rates mortality and morbidity) (Option C ruled out) Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination. Intensive monitoring for sepsis. Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing. Skin grafting post-infection control. The testes remain unaffected (Option D) in this condition as they have the dual blood supply. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page, 1573-1574. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page, 1372.

questions.question: What type of hernia is a funicular hernia? Direct inguinal hernia
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Indirect inguinal hernia Explanation: Funicular hernia is a type of indirect Inguinal Hernia . Feature Indirect Inguinal Hernia Direct Inguinal Hernia (Option A ruled out) Common in Young adults Elderly Course It enters through the deep inguinal ring, traverses the inguinal canal, and exits via the superficial inguinal ring. Protrudes directly through Hesselbach's triangle Relation to Spermatic Cord Anterolateral to the spermatic cord Posterior to the spermatic cord Location of Neck of Sac Above and medial to the pubic tubercle. Lies within the Hesselbach's triangle. Relation to Inferior Epigastric vessels Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. Medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Relation to Scrotum Descends into the scrotum Does not Descend Types Bubonocele: Confined to inguinal canal Funicular: Processus vaginalis closed above epididymis, hernia content distinct from testis (Option B) Complete/Scrotal: Testis in the lower part of the hernia — Femoral hernia (Option C) occurs when abdominal contents push through the femoral canal, located below the inguinal ligament, and is more common in women due to a wider pelvis. It differs from funicular or inguinal hernias as it is not associated with the inguinal canal and carries a higher risk of complications like incarceration or strangulation. Umbilical hernia (Option D) occurs when part of the intestine or abdominal tissue protrudes near the navel. It is more common in infants but can affect adults, often due to obesity or increased intra-abdominal pressure. Unlike inguinal hernias, it is not related to the inguinal canal or processus vaginalis. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1065-1066.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Transurethral resection of the tumor Explanation: In the case of a 2x2 cm bladder mass indicative of low-grade transitional cell carcinoma, the preferred initial treatment is Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor (TURBT) . It is the initial management of bladder tumours for accurate staging. (Option A) It is performed using a cystoscope inserted through the urethra to remove the tumor from the bladder. It allows for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes (tumor is removed and sent for histopathological examination). Large tumours: Standard fractionated resection of the entire tumour (tumour base with deep muscle). Small tumors (<3 cm): En bloc resection of the entire tumour (solitary tumor) The following details should be recorded to enable accurate risk stratification: Size of the primary tumour Number of tumours Nodular or papillary features Presence of CIS Completeness of visual resection. Mapping biopsies (if CIS suspected): Taken from trigone, bladder dome and the right, left, anterior and posterior bladder wall. Tumor Stage Tis (Carcinoma in situ) TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor) May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed Intravesical BCG Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36 Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy Up to 3 years Ta (Non-muscle invasive) TURBT Complete resection of tumor Low-risk: Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical

questions.question: Which of the following will have unilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Retrocaval ureter Explanation: Retrocaval ureter is one of the causes of unilateral Hydronephrosis (HN) . It is an aseptic dilatation of pelvicalyceal system due to partial or intermittent obstruction to the outflow of urine. Causes: Unilateral Hydronephrosis Bilateral Hydronephrosis Extramural Causes: Advanced Malignancies Colorectal cancer Carcinoma cervix Carcinoma Prostate Retroperitoneal fibrosis Retrocaval Ureter (Option D) Congenital Causes: Posterior Urethral Valve (Option B ruled out) Urethral atresia (Option A ruled out) Intramural Causes: PUJ Obstruction Ureterocele Ureteric Stricture Urothelial tumor Acquired Causes: Bladder neck stenosis BPH (Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia) (Option C ruled out) CA Prostate Urethral strictures Intraluminal Causes: Stone Papillary Slough Due to: Analgesic nephropathy Sickle cell anemia Clinical features: Unilateral Hydronephrosis Bilateral Hydronephrosis Congenital PUJ obstruction and calculus are the most common causes Male to Female ratio 2:1 Right side kidney is affected more commonly From lower urinary tract obstruction: Loin pain Features of bladder outlet obstruction—frequency, hesitancy, poor stream Kidneys are not palpable if renal failure develops early Dull aching loin pain with dragging sensation or heaviness Mass in the loin which moves with respiration Dietl's crisis (Intermittent Hydronephrosis) : Swelling in the loin after acute renal colic, disappears after passing a large volume of urine Dysuria, haematuria. If infected, fever and tenderness in the renal angle From bilateral upper urinary tract obstruction: Loin pain, mass in the loin, attacks of renal colic In severe cases, features of renal failure like oliguria, edema, and hiccoughs may be present Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page, 1000-1002.

questions.question: A 44-year-old lady presents to the hospital with a ballotable flank mass. The mass measures 4 cm on CT imaging. Urine examination shows malignant cells. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Partial nephrectomy Explanation: A 4 cm ballotable flank mass with a CT scan showing a hyper-enhancing solid renal mass suggests Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) , with partial nephrectomy being the preferred treatment for tumors smaller than 4 cm. Management RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant. Surgical Management: Partial Nephrectomy: Involves removing only the tumor while preserving the remainder of the kidney. (Option A) Indications: T1 Disease(<7cm) Restricted to poles RCC in solitary functioning kidney Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim. (Option C ruled out) Indications: Larger tumors or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible Ablative Techniques Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation: Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures. Indications: Patients who are not surgical candidates Patients with small tumors(T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm). Systemic Therapy (For advanced/ metastatic disease) Targeted Therapy Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib) mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus) Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab) Partial nephrectomy + Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (Option B): Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is typically used for muscle-invasive or high-risk RCC, which isn't the case here. With a 4 cm localized tumor, RCC generally doesn't respond well to chemotherapy, and partial nephrectomy alone is sufficient. Radical nephrectomy + Postoperative radiotherapy (Option D): Postoperative radiotherapy is not typically used for RCC due to its resistance to radiation. Radical nephrectomy is reserved for larger or invasive tumors, while partial

questions.question: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for the condition shown in the image, where the size of the stone is 1.5 cm?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ureteroscopy Explanation: A 2 mm stone in the ureter is managed by ureteroscopy, a minimally invasive procedure that uses a flexible tube inserted through the urethra and bladder to remove or fragment stones smaller than 2 cm. Conservative management of Renal Stones: Indications Upto 5 mm in size Non dilated ureter Stone located in the lower third of the ureter Progressive downward movement on repeated scan Increased fluid intake to promote diuresis and stone passage Medical expulsive therapy (MET) Involves the use of alpha-blocker medications (e.g., tamsulosin) or calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) Helps to relax the ureter smooth muscle, facilitating the spontaneous passage of the stone Typically recommended for stones up to 10 mm in size. Intervention (if the stone fails to pass or symptoms worsen) Ureteroscopic stone extraction (Option B) It allows fragmentation and removal of stones smaller than 2 cm from the ureter or kidney. Avoided in <5 years ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy) (Option C ruled out) Radiolucent or radiopaque renal or ureteric stones less than 2 cm in diameter Stones located in the renal pelvis, upper, or middle ureter Patients with normal renal function and no severe hydronephrosis Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) (Option A ruled out) To extract stones from the kidney through a dilated tract. For stones larger than 2 cm. Regular follow-up with imaging to monitor stone location and size ESWL (Option C): is incorrect because while ESWL can be considered for renal or proximal ureteric stones <2 cm , its effectiveness drops as the stone approaches 1.5

questions.question: What is the initial management approach for urinary symptoms in a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Tamsulosin Explanation: The initial treatment for a patient with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) is Tamsulosin, an α -1 blocker. Management Medical Management 1st line management: I 1 Blocker Prazosin Terazosin Silodosin Most commonly used: Tamsulosin ( I 1A selective Blocker) (Option B) 2nd line: 5 I Reductase inhibitors Finasteride (Option C ruled out) Dutasteride Triptorelin pamoate Combination treatment with I 1 Blocker and 5 I Reductase inhibitors are used in large prostate. Surgical Management Indications: No improvement in medical management. Acute retention of urine Chronic urinary retention with residual urine of more than 200 ml. Complications like hydroureter, hydronephrosis, stone formation, recurrent infection, and gross haematuria Surgeries: Gold standard- TURP (Trans urethral resection of prostate). (Option A ruled out) Trans urethral incision of prostate (TUIP) Open prostatectomy procedures Acute management in urinary retention: urethral catheterization and if it fails - suprapubic cystostomy (SPC). Observation (Option D) may be suitable for mild, asymptomatic BPH cases that don’t significantly affect quality of life, with regular monitoring and lifestyle changes. However, if symptoms worsen, medications like Tamsulosin are typically recommended, as observation alone is not the standard initial treatment for urinary symptoms. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1526-1529

questions.question: Which of the following are true about nephroblastoma except:

options.A: Treatment is chemotherapy followed by surgery
options.D: Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children Explanation: Nephroblastoma, or Wilms Tumor, is the most common primary renal malignancy in childhood and the 2nd most common intraabdominal malignancy ( neuroblastoma being the most common ) in children, typically affecting those aged 2 to 5 years. Cause Caused by mutations in WT1 and WT2 genes on chromosome 11. Associated syndromes Denys-Drash Syndrome (DDS): A rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the WT1 gene, characterized by a triad of Wilms' tumor, nephrotic syndrome due to diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and male pseudohermaphroditism WAGR Syndrome: A rare genetic condition caused by a deletion on chromosome 11p13, leading to a combination of Wilms' tumor, aniridia (absence of the iris), genitourinary abnormalities, and intellectual disability. Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS): A genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, increased tumor risk, macroglossia, abdominal wall defects, and hemihyperplasia, often due to abnormalities on chromosome 11p15.5. Perlman Syndrome: A rare genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, developmental delay, intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and an increased risk of Wilms' tumor, often caused by mutations in the DIS3L2 gene. Clinical Presentation Most common malignant pediatric renal tumor. Triad: Asymptomatic abdominal mass (MC presentation) Fever (disappears after tumor resection) Hematuria (Gross/Microscopic) Rarely : Pain Investigations USG- Primary investigation CECT- Investigation of choice. MRI - For better soft tissue visualization. Treatment Chemotherapy followed by surgery. (Option A ruled out) Multimodal approach Surgery : Radical nephrectomy or nephron-sparing surgery Chemotherapy : VCD regimen Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Dactinomycin/Doxorubicin Radiation therapy : For higher stages or unfavorable histology Staging I. Disease confined to the kidney and completely resectable II . Tumor extends beyond the kidney but can be excised completely Ill . Residual disease after resection with positive lymph nodes and massive spillage IV . Blood-borne metastasis V . Bilateral disease Prognosis Most important Prognostic Factor - Histology > Stage Metastasis Mainly through a hematogenous route into: (Option C ruled out) Lungs (MC) (Option B ruled out) Liver Bones (Rarely) Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page, 1012-1013.

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presents to the surgical OPD with a painless left inguinal reducible mass. On examination cough impulse is positive. After further investigations, the patient is diagnosed with an inguinal hernia. What is the surgical management of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hernioplasty Explanation: Hernioplasty is the preferred surgical approach for Inguinal Hernia in adults, involving the repair of the hernia with synthetic mesh to strengthen the abdominal wall and prevent recurrence. Management of Inguinal Hernia Surgical Approaches: Herniotomy : It involves excising and closing the hernia sac Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele. In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates. (Option A ruled out) Hernioplasty : Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh (preferred in adults). (Option B) Indications: Direct hernia Recurrent hernia, Re-recurrent hernia lncisional hernia Old age Hernia with weak abdominal muscle tone Sliding hernia. Herniorrhaphy : Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures Techniques: Bassini's Repair: Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair. Higher recurrence rates. Shouldice Repair: involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's. Modified Shouldice : A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement. Anterior Tension-Free Repair: Lichtenstein Repair : Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery. It is a a tension-free, simple, fat, polypropylene mesh repair for inguinal hernia. (Option A) Open Preperitoneal Repair: Stoppa Repair : Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia Laparoscopic Hernia Repair: Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair Wait and watch (Option C) may be considered for small, asymptomatic hernias in low-risk patients, but in this case, surgical intervention is recommended to prevent complications like incarceration or strangulation, as inguinal hernias do not resolve on their own. Emergency laparotomy (Option D) is reserved for incarcerated or strangulated hernias with compromised blood supply or bowel obstruction, not necessary for this reducible and painless hernia.

questions.question: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Horseshoe kidney Explanation: The patient, who presents with hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infections, is diagnosed with Horseshoe Kidney , as indicated by a CT abdomen revealing the fusion of the two kidneys at their lower ends, forming a U-shaped structure. Horseshoe Kidney It is a congenital condition in which the two kidneys are fused at the lower ends, forming a U-shaped structure. Cause During fetal development the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure. This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen. Clinical Features Mostly asymptomatic. Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones. Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) Hydronephrosis Hematuria Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain. Investigation CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualization of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications. CT Abdomen showing Horseshoe kidney Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include : Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the " Hand Joining Sign ." High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters. Management Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment, but should be monitored periodically. Symptomatic Patients: UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty Kidney Stones: Management

questions.question: Which is the correct sequence for the correction of hypospadias? Urethroplasty Penile de-gloving Orthoplasty Glanuloplasty
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2,3,1,4 Explanation: The correct sequence for the correction of Hypospadias is 2,3,1,4 Caused by failure of fusion of urethral folds- meatus in ventral aspect Affects about 1 in 300 male live births, The most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. Characterized by: Ectopic ventrally located urethral meatus, Ventral penile curvature (chordee), Incomplete dorsal hood prepuce. Classification/Types: Glanular Hypospadias: Most common type Coronal Hypospadias Penile Hypospadias Penoscrotal Hypospadias Perineal Hypospadias Scrotal Hypospadias Distal penile Hypospadias Hypospadias Repair Steps De-gloving → Orthoplasty → Urethroplasty → Meatoplasty → Glanuloplasty → Penoplasty → Scrotoplasty Degloving : Removal of the penile skin to expose the underlying structures. (Statement 2) Orthoplasty : Correction of penile curvature and any associated penile shaft issues. This step involves mobilising and repositioning the urethral plate if necessary. (Statement 3) Urethroplasty : Creation or reconstruction of the neourethra using tissue flaps or grafts to form a functional urethra. (Statement 1) Providing vascularised coverage for the urethroplasty. Glanuloplasty : Reconstruction of the glans penis, focusing on creating a normal appearance and aligning the meatus. (Statement 4) Penoplasty : Reconstruction of the penile shaft to restore or enhance its normal appearance and function. This may involve skin flaps or grafts. Scrotoplasty : Correction or reconstruction of the scrotum, which may be necessary if there are associated anomalies or for cosmetic reasons. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1539-1540. Steps

questions.question: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a pelvic fracture following blunt abdominal trauma. No blood is seen at the meatus. Catheterisation does not produce significant urine output. The radiological image is given below. What is the next step in management?

options.D: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.explanation: catheterisation, along with radiological findings suggestive of Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture , indicate that immediate laparotomy is required. Intraperitoneal Bladder Rupture Involves a tear or injury to the peritoneum over the bladder, and urine leaks into the peritoneal cavity in males. Causes Often occurs in a fully distended bladder, usually due to trauma or injury Clinical Features Sudden, severe pain in the suprapubic region. Signs of shock and syncope. Diffuse abdominal pain with later features of peritonitis. Abdominal distension. Haematuria Absence of desire to urinate Diagnosis Plain X-ray: It may show a ground glass appearance. Peritoneal Tap: Used to collect urine from the abdominal cavity. Cystography: Iodine dye is injected via a catheter to visualise bladder tears and the dye entry into the peritoneal cavity. The contrast outlines the bowel loops. Ultrasound: To assess other abdominal injuries. Treatment Emergency Laparotomy is required. (Option C) . Bladder tear is sutured with polylactic acid (vicryl) in two layers. Peritoneal wash to clean out the peritoneal cavity. Separate drainage for prevesical space and peritoneal cavity. Administration of specific antibiotics to prevent sepsis. Catheterisation: Malecot’s catheter is placed suprapubically. Foley's catheter passed urethrally. Complications Cystitis /and pyelonephritis. Peritonitis. Pelvic abscess. Fistula formation (vesicovaginal or rectovesical). Paralytic ileus. Hemorrhage. Suprapubic cystostomy (Option A) is used to divert urine in cases of bladder injuries, but it’s typically considered when there is a lower urinary tract injury, such as bladder rupture without peritoneal involvement. Per Urethral catheterisation (Option B) is performed to assess for urethral injury or urinary retention.

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a young girl who presents with continuous dribbling of urine despite voiding normally, as reported by her parents, who mention her never being completely dry since birth?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Ectopic ureter Explanation: In females, an ectopic ureter opens below the sphincter into the urethra or vagina. It presents as continuous urinary dribbling despite normal voiding. Diagnosis is based on history and confirmed by excretory urography. An intravenous dye, such as indigo carmine, can help visualise the ectopic orifice. Ureterocele (Option B) Would present with recurrent UTIs, voiding difficulty , and bladder outlet obstruction rather than continuous dribbling. Congenital megaureter (Option C) Typically presents with hydronephrosis and recurrent UTIs , not continuous dribbling. Vesicoureteric reflux (Option D) Causes recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis but does not cause continuous dribbling from birth. Reference: Bailey and Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1467

questions.question: A 1-month-old child is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the next step of management for this child?

options.B: Surgical exploration within the next 2 weeks
options.D: Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months.

questions.explanation: Correct answer D) Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months Explanation: Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism) Definition Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen. Locations Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80% Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20% Causes and Associated Conditions Developmental and Genetic Factors: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome and testosterone imbalances can impair testicular descent. Prematurity and Maternal Factors: Premature birth and maternal issues like diabetes or medication exposure can lead to undescended testes. Mechanical and Physical Factors: Obstructions in the inguinal canal, scrotum, or related conditions such as inguinal hernia can prevent normal testicular descent. Complications (SATHI Mnemonic): S: Sterility - Elevated abdominal temperature can impair sperm production, leading to potential infertility if untreated. A: Atrophy - Prolonged exposure to heat can cause the testis to shrink or become non-functional. T: Trauma, Tumor, Torsion - Increased risk of testicular torsion, which can cause severe pain and potentially result in testicular loss. The most common tumor associated is seminoma with the highest risk of tumor development in abdominal testes. H: Hernia - Over 90% of cases are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of inguinal hernia. I: Inflammation - The undescended testis is more prone to inflammatory conditions. Note: Leydig cells are unaffected, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis. Diagnosis Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration. Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy. Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilized to locate the testis. Treatment Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option D) Types of Orchidopexy Ombridannes Keetley-Torek Stephen-Fowler Ladd & Gross Surgical exploration within 2 weeks (Option A) is not the first step. Karyotyping is needed before surgery to rule out a disorder of sexual development. Perform orchidopexy now (Option B) : Orchidopexy is performed between 6-12 months , but this case requires karyotyping first to rule out DSD before any surgical decision. Wait and watch for spontaneous descent within the next 6 months (Option C): Spontaneous descent may occur in unilateral cryptorchidism , but bilateral cases require urgent evaluation due to the risk of DSD . Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page 1559 -1561. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery (11th Edition), Page 1777. SRB's Manual of Surgery (6th Edition), Page 1065 -1068.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
