questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Uric Acid Stones Explanation: Radiopaque stones: Calcium Oxalate Stones (Option A ruled out) Calcium Phosphate Stones Struvite Stones Cystine stones are also mildly radiopaque (Option C ruled out) Radiolucent stones include: Uric acid stones (most common) (Option B) Xanthine stones (rarely seen, mainly in patients with xanthinuria) (Option D ruled out) Stone Type Features Image Calcium Oxalate The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones) ; Radiopaque Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia Types: monohydrate (dumbbell-shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped) I I II I I Calcium Phosphate Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare Types include apatite and brushite stones Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis. I II Struvite Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate) Radiopaque Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter ) II I I II Cystine Radiopaque , Constitute approximately 1% of stones Result from cystinuria , an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine. Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds Uric Acid Radiolucent Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine.

questions.question: For which of the following conditions is the Whitaker test recommended?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Hydronephrosis Explanation: Whitaker test Feature Details Definition A urodynamic test that measures the pressure gradient between the renal pelvis and bladder to assess upper urinary tract obstruction. Indications Equivocal cases of upper urinary tract obstruction, PUJ obstruction, post-pyeloplasty evaluation, distinguishing true obstruction from hydronephrosis. Procedure 1. Percutaneous nephrostomy placed in the renal pelvis. 2. Bladder catheter inserted for pressure measurement. 3. Fluid infusion into renal pelvis at 10 ml/min. 4. Pressure difference between renal pelvis & bladder recorded. Interpretation <15 cm H I O → No obstruction. 15–22 cm H I O → Indeterminate (needs further evaluation). >22 cm H I O → Significant obstruction present. Advantages Helps differentiate true obstruction vs. non-obstructive dilation. Useful in post-surgical cases. Limitations Invasive (rarely used due to modern imaging). Replaced by diuretic renal scan (DTPA/EC scan) & MR Urography. Posterior urethral valve (Option B) PUV is a lower urinary tract obstruction (at the urethra), and the Whitaker test assesses upper tract obstruction . Best Test: Voiding Cystourethrogram (VCUG). Urethral atresia Congenital absence of urethral patency (Option C) is usually diagnosed prenatally or at birth. Whitaker test is not needed , as the condition is identified early with fetal ultrasound . Urethral stricture (Option D) Affects the lower urinary tract, while the Whitaker test evaluates upper urinary tract obstruction. Best Test: Retrograde Urethrogram (RUG) or Uroflowmetry. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25015627/

questions.question: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt with dilated veins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Varicocele Explanation: Varicocele : Dilatation and tortuosity of the pampiniform plexus of veins and testicular veins. Varicocele Common Occurrence More common in tall, thin young men More frequent on the left side but can be bilateral Causes Idiopathic Absence or incompetent valve at the junction of the left testicular vein and left renal vein Perpendicular entry of the left testicular vein into the left renal vein Left-sided renal cell carcinoma causing blockage of the left testicular vein Effects Increased temperature in the scrotum, depressing spermatogenesis and causing infertility Symptoms Swelling at the root of the scrotum Dragging pain in the groin and scrotum "Bag of worms" feeling Impulse on coughing Swelling reduces on lying down (except in renal cell carcinoma) Investigations Venous Doppler of the scrotum and groin Ultrasound of the abdomen to check for kidney tumours Semen analysis Treatment Palomo's Operation: Suprainguinal extraperitoneal ligation of the testicular vein Ligation of veins Excision of veins Hydrocele (Option A) is an abnormal collection of serous fluid in some part of the processus vaginalis, usually the tunica. Testicular torsion (Option C) is seen in a teenager or young adult male. It is easily missed. Pain can be referred to the right iliac fossa, and appendicitis will be suspected unless the scrotum is examined. Epididymo Orchitis (Option D) is intrascrotal swelling, most common among intra-scrotal swelling. It is usually caused as a result of the retrograde ascent of Pathogens.

questions.question: What would be the best treatment option for a patient who has been diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma and has a tumour measuring 10 cm in size, located at the lower part of the kidney, and has negative regional lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Radical nephrectomy Explanation: Tumor size: The tumour is 10 cm, which classifies it as T2 RCC (T2a if 7–10 cm, T2b if >10 cm but still confined to the kidney). Location: Since the tumour is large and located in the lower part of the kidney, a partial nephrectomy is not feasible due to a high risk of incomplete resection or complications. No lymph node involvement: There is no evidence of metastasis (N0M0), making surgery the best option. Partial nephrectomy (Option B) Indicated for tumours <7 cm (T1) when feasible. A 10 cm tumour is too large for nephron-sparing surgery. Radiotherapy (Option C) RCC is chemo-resistant . Systemic therapy is considered only for metastatic disease (stage IV). Chemotherapy (Option D) Chemotherapy isn't generally advised for renal cell carcinoma. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 2091, 2092

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who has a scrotal mass on the left side that is hard in texture, has uneven edges, does not decrease in size when lying down or manipulated, does not have a cough impulse, but shows enlargement in the para-aortic lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Correct answer D) Metastasizing testicular tumor Explanation: Scrotal mass on the left side → indicate a testicular pathology. Hard texture with uneven edges → Indicative of a solid tumor , likely testicular cancer (e.g., seminoma or non-seminomatous germ cell tumor). Does not decrease in size when lying down or manipulated → Rules out conditions like hydrocele or hernia . No cough impulse → Further rules out an inguinal hernia . Enlarged para-aortic lymph nodes → Strongly indicates metastatic spread from a testicular malignancy , as testicular tumors typically metastasize to retroperitoneal (para-aortic) lymph nodes . Hydrocele (Option A ) Soft, cystic , transilluminates, and size decreases on lying down . No involvement of para-aortic lymph nodes . Direct Inguinal Hernia (Option B) Usually reducible , with a positive cough impulse . Does not cause para-aortic lymph node enlargement. Indirect Inguinal Hernia (Option C) Often soft, reducible , and may extend into the scrotum . Positive cough impulse . Does not cause para-aortic lymph node enlargement. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563159/?utm_source

questions.question: A 10-month-old male baby presented with an empty scrotum. Ultrasonography revealed that the right testis was found in the right inguinal canal, while the left testis was found in the perineum. Comment on the diagnosis of this baby.

options.C: Right-side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis
options.D: Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis

questions.explanation: of undescended testis the testis is usually found in the route at which it descends, such as the inguinal canal. In the above patient, the right testis was found in the inguinal canal. In ectopic testis, the testis is found in places other than the route of descent of the testis, as in this case, the left testis is seen in the perineum. Hence, the correct choice is Right-side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis. Bilateral undescended testis (Option A) The left testis is found in the perineum, which is indicative of ectopic testis. Bilateral ectopic testis (Option B) The right testis is found in the inguinal canal, which is indicative of an undescended testis. Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis (Option D) The right testis is found in the inguinal canal and is indicative of undescended testi,s whereas the left side is found in the perineum which is indicative of ectopic testis. Ectopic testis An ectopic testis is when a testicle fails to descend into the scrotum and lies outside the normal descent tract, typically due to abnormalities in the gubernaculum Management: Surgical Correction (Orchidopexy): To reposition the testis into the scrotum. Complications: Infertility Increased risk of testicular cancer

questions.question: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 14-year-old boy who is experiencing sudden scrotal pain, where physical examination reveals a swollen and red scrotum with the right testes being retracted, absent cremasteric reflex, and negative Prehn's sign?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Right testicular torsion Explanation: In the case of torsion of the testis, the testicular clinical features include an empty, swollen scrotum, which is edematous on the side of the lesion. Tender lump at the external abdominal ring. Elevation of the scrotum increases pain. Right-sided hydrocele (Option A) Hydrocele presents with a painless swelling. No sudden pain is seen in the right-sided hydrocele. Hence, it is not the correct choice. Strangulated inguinal hernia (Option B) In the case of a strangulated inguinal hernia, the scrotum will show ischemic changes but will not be edematous. Right epididymo orchitis (Option D) It is an inflammation of the epididymis. It is caused by a bacterial infection and presents as a swelling on the posterior aspect of the epididymis. Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 1068-1070

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for an elderly male patient who has come to the hospital with lower back pain, a movable mass in the lower back that becomes more prominent when breathing in and a general feeling of weakness? The lab tests show the presence of red blood cells in the urine, with no sign of pus cells.
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Renal cell carcinoma Explanation: Renal cell carcinoma is a type of kidney cancer that originates in the cells of the kidney tubules. It commonly presents with symptoms such as persistent back pain, a palpable mass in the lumbar region, fatigue, and hematuria. The presence of RBCs in the urine without pus cells, along with lumbar pain and a ballotable mass, is consistent with renal cell carcinoma. Polycystic kidney disease (Option A) Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of multiple cysts in the kidneys. It typically presents with symptoms such as abdominal or flank pain, hypertension, and enlarged kidneys. While PKD can cause hematuria (blood in the urine), the presence of a ballotable mass and lumbar pain during inspiration is not commonly associated with PKD. Hydronephrosis (Option B) Hydronephrosis refers to the swelling or enlargement of the kidney due to the buildup of urine caused by an obstruction in the urinary tract. It can result from conditions such as kidney stones, tumours, or structural abnormalities. While hydronephrosis can cause lumbar pain and a ballotable mass in the affected area, the presence of RBCs in the urine without pus cells suggests an alternative diagnosis. Chronic pyelonephritis (Option D) Chronic pyelonephritis is a long-term inflammation of the kidney resulting from recurrent urinary tract infections. It may cause symptoms such as flank pain, fever, frequent urination, and the presence of pus cells in the urine. However, the absence of pus cells and the presence of RBCs in the urine, along with the presence of a ballotable mass, are not typical for chronic pyelonephritis. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page - 1483 to 1485

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a 60-year-old male who is experiencing lower back pain and has sclerotic lesions in the vertebrae?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Carcinoma prostate Explanation: The most likely primary cancer site associated with sclerotic lesions in the vertebrae in a 60-year-old male is carcinoma prostate. Prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to the bones, including the vertebrae, leading to sclerotic (hardened) lesions. Carcinoma Prostate with Bone Metastases: Aspect Details Pathophysiology Prostate cancer spreads hematogenously to bones , commonly affecting the spine, pelvis, ribs, and femur . Metastases are osteoblastic (sclerotic) due to increased osteoblast activity. Common Symptoms Lower back pain , pathological fractures, urinary symptoms (hesitancy, frequency), and neurological deficits if spinal cord compression occurs . Laboratory Findings PSA – Elevated , ALP – Elevated (bone involvement), Serum Calcium – Normal/mildly elevated (osteoblastic metastases do not cause severe hypercalcemia). X-ray Findings Sclerotic (osteoblastic) lesions in vertebrae, pelvis, and long bones. Bone Scan (Tc-99m) Shows increased radiotracer uptake in metastatic sites (best for early detection). MRI Spine Detects spinal cord compression marrow infiltration . CT Pelvis/Spine Defines bone metastases and local spread . Confirmatory Test TRUS-guided prostate biopsy (Transrectal Ultrasound Biopsy). Treatment Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) (GnRH agonists like Leuprolide), Bisphosphonates for bone health , Radiation for spinal metastases , and Surgical decompression if cord compression occurs . Tuberculosis (Option B) Tuberculosis (TB) typically affects the lungs, but it can also involve other organs, including the spine. Spinal tuberculosis, known as Pott's disease, can cause vertebral destruction and collapse, leading to back pain. Renal cell carcinoma (Option C) Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a type of kidney cancer. While it can metastasize to the bones, including the vertebrae, it typically presents with lytic (destructive) lesions rather than sclerotic lesions. Carcinoma colon (Option D) Colorectal cancer can metastasize to the bones, including the Vertebrae. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1531-1534

questions.question: A patient with a history of trauma has a ruptured bulbar urethra. What is the location for the accumulation of urine?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Superficial pouch Explanation: The superficial pouch, also known as the superficial perineal space or superficial perineal compartment, is an anatomical space located between the perineal membrane and the superficial fascia. It contains various structures, including the root of the penis, the bulb of the penis (which includes the bulbar urethra in males), and associated muscles. If the bulbar urethra is ruptured, urine can potentially leak into the superficial pouch and accumulate there. Deep pouch (Option A) The deep pouch (Space of Retzius) , also known as the space of Retzius, is an extraperitoneal space located between the pubic symphysis and the anterior bladder wall. It is situated in the lower abdomen and is not directly involved in the accumulation of urine in the case of a ruptured bulbar urethra. Rectouterine pouch (Option C) The rectouterine pouch (Pouch of Douglas) , also referred to as the pouch of Douglas, is a peritoneal space located between the posterior wall of the uterus (in females) or the bladder (in males) and the anterior wall of the rectum. Uterovesical pouch (Option D) The uterovesical pouch (Vesicouterine pouch) , also called the vesicouterine pouch, is a peritoneal space located between the uterus and the bladder in females. Urethral injury Urethral injuries refer to damage to the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body. Anterior vs. Posterior Urethral Injuries Feature Anterior Urethral Injury Posterior Urethral Injury Location Bulbar urethra (most common) Penile urethra Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common) Prostatic urethra Common Causes Straddle injuries Direct trauma Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy) Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds) Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents) Blunt trauma Clinical Features Hematuria (blood in urine) Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma) Perineal pain Urinary retention or difficulty voiding Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma Blood at the meatus Inability to void High-riding prostate on rectal exam Perineal or suprapubic pain Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures Possible concomitant bladder injury Investigations Retrograde Urethrography (RGU) : Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

questions.question: In a newborn male with an undeveloped scrotum, the testis was observed to be located near the peritoneum. Which of the following factors aids in the descent of the testis into the scrotum?

options.D: Manually bring the testis down to the bottom of scrotum.

questions.explanation: Correct answer A) GnRH Analogue Explanation: GnRH analogue increases the level of gonadotropin,s which further increases the level of androgens that help in testicular descent as it is an androgen-dependent process. Testosterone (Option B) GnRH analogue is preferred over testosterone as neonatal gonadotropin therapy can increase the testosterone levels without fear of inducing spermatogenesis or negatively affecting an ultimate number of Sertoli cells (an important determinant of fertility). Cold Compressions (Option C) Cold compresses or ice application is not a recognised method to assist testicular descent in newborns. Manually bring the testis down to the bottom of the scrotum (Option D). This option describes a manual technique called orchidopexy or surgical orchiopexy. It involves surgically bringing the undescended testis down to the scrotum. It is a definitive treatment for undescended testis, but it is typically performed by a healthcare professional and not manually by parents or Caregivers. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1559 -1561. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 1777. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1065 -1068.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with scrotal enlargement. His LDH levels are notably elevated, while HCG and alpha-fetoprotein levels remain within normal ranges. Upon histopathological examination, the findings are as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Seminoma Explanation: Seminoma Feature Details Tumor Type Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumour in men aged 25-45 Origin Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules Clinical Features Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia Diagnostic Markers AFP: Normal hCG: Normal or mildly elevated LDH: Elevated Investigation Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli FNAC: Contraindicated due to the risk of tumour cell seeding and lymph node metastasis Treatment Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy Adjuvant: Radiation therapy or chemotherapy for positive lymph nodes Leydig cell tumour (Option A) : Benign testicular tumour that typically occurs in adults aged 30-60. While it presents as a painless testicular mass, Leydig cell tumours don't typically elevate beta-hCG. Embryonal carcinoma (Option B) : Aggressive germ cell tumour that often occurs in young men. However, it typically presents with both elevated AFP and beta-hCG, not just beta-hCG alone. It's also usually more heterogeneous on ultrasound. Teratoma (Option D): Typically occurs in young men and usually presents with normal tumour markers (both beta-hCG and AFP). On ultrasound, it appears heterogeneous with both cystic and solid components.

questions.question: A young male underwent lumbar sympathectomy, and bilateral L1 ganglions were removed. What will be the most common side effect?
questions.explanation: sympathetic innervation responsible for controlling the closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation. This disruption can lead to retrograde ejaculation, where semen enters the bladder instead of being expelled through the penis during ejaculation. Retrograde ejaculation is a known and frequently reported side effect of lumbar sympathectomy. Impotence (Erectile Dysfunction) (Option A) Erection is mainly parasympathetically mediated (S2-S4, pelvic splanchnic nerves), not lumbar sympathetic nerves. Sympathectomy may affect ejaculation but does not typically cause impotence. Bladder Dysfunction (Option C) The main control of bladder function (detrusor contraction, micturition reflex) is via S2-S4 parasympathetic fibers , not L1 sympathetic nerves. Some mild urinary dysfunction may occur , but retrograde ejaculation is more common. Incontinence (Option D) Urinary continence is maintained by external urethral sphincter control (somatic, pudendal nerve - S2-S4) , which remains intact after L1 sympathectomy. Reference: sympathectomy

questions.question: All the following are features of polycystic disease of kidneys except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Erythrocytosis Explanation: Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is characterized by multiple renal cysts , leading to progressive renal failure . The key clinical features include hematuria, hypertension, and renal failure . However, erythrocytosis (increased RBC count) is not a typical feature because PKD often leads to chronic kidney disease (CKD) , which is associated with anemia rather than polycythemia. Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD) Feature Explanation Hematuria Due to rupture of cysts into the renal collecting system Hypertension Result of renin-angiotensin system (RAS) activation due to ischemia from cyst compression Renal failure Progressive cyst expansion leads to nephron loss, causing chronic kidney disease (CKD) Erythrocytosis (Absent) CKD leads to decreased erythropoietin (EPO) , resulting in anemia rather than polycythemia Characteristics ADPKD ARPKD Affected age group Adults Children Cysts Are present in both outer and inner surfaces Present only on the inner surface. Involved gene PKD 1 on chromosome 16 PKD 2 on chromosome 4 PKHD on chromosome 6 (Statement 2) Protein affected polycystin Fibrocystin (Statement 3) Histology Complications Coronary or hypertensive heart disease (40%). (Statement 4) Infection (25%). Ruptured berry aneurysm or hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage (15%). Neonatal period: Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia. Renal failure. Childhood and adolescence: Progressive renal failure leading to ESRD. Complications of CKD. Complications from hepatic fibrosis. Images Hematuria (Option A): Incorrect because it is a common feature due to cyst rupture. Hypertension (Option B): Incorrect because it occurs due to RAS activation. Renal failure (Option C): Incorrect because PKD leads to progressive CKD and ESRD .

questions.question: A 26 year old male presented with a painless large round firm right testicular swelling, with a dragging sensation. The left testis was normal. AFP was around 3000U. What is the next best step in the management?
questions.explanation: elevated AFP level is high inguinal orchidectomy as these findings are suggestive of testicular tumor probably non seminomatous germ cell tumor due to raised AFP levels. An inguinal orchidectomy is commonlyperformed as a treatment for testicular cancer or for other conditions such as testicular torsion or certain cases of transgender surgery. FNAC (Option A) is not recommended in the management of testicular masses. Scrotal true cut biopsy (Option B) A high inguinal orchidectomy is the preferred approach for the management of suspected testicular malignancies. Repeat tumor markers (Option D) An elevated AFP level in the context of a testicular mass requires further evaluation and definitive management rather than repeating tumor markers. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1569- 1572

questions.question: A 20-year-old was brought to the ER after falling off his bicycle. His vitals were stable, but he had a bruise over the perineum, and he had not passed urine yet. Blood was seen at the meatus and the bladder was not palpable. How do you manage him?

options.B: Immediate insertion of a Foley catheter
options.D: Wait for bladder to fill and urge to urinate

questions.explanation: the management would be to wait for the bladder to fill and for the patient to have an urge to urinate. This is done to ensure the urethral integrity. Wait and send him home (Option A) there are indications of potential urethral injury, and therefore, the patient should be managed actively rather than being sent home without intervention. Immediate insertion of Foley's catheter (Option B) inserting a Foley catheter without assessing urethral integrity can lead to further complications. Suprapubic aspiration of urine (Option C) is not the initial management approach in this scenario. The bladder needs to be filled and the urge to urinate needs to be assessed before considering invasive measures. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, pages 1540- 1542

questions.question: What is the primary reason for bladder outlet obstruction in male children?
questions.explanation: children. PUV is an abnormal fold of tissue within the urethra that obstructs the flow of urine. It is a congenital condition that occurs during foetal development. PUV can cause various urinary symptoms, such as difficulty urinating, weak urinary stream, urinary tract infections, and urinary retention. It is more commonly seen in male infants. Urethral atresia (Option B) is a rare condition in which the urethra is completely closed or absent. It is a congenital anomaly and can lead to urinary retention and other urinary complications. While urethral atresia can cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is not as common as the posterior urethral valve in male children. Anterior urethral valve (Option C) is a less common condition compared to the posterior urethral valve. It is characterised by abnormal tissue folds or membranes in the anterior portion of the urethra. Anterior urethral valve can cause urinary obstruction and other urinary symptoms, but it is not the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children. Ureterocele (Option D) is a bulging of the ureter into the bladder. It can obstruct the flow of urine from the affected kidney. While ureterocele can lead to urinary obstruction, it primarily affects the upper urinary tract rather than the bladder outlet. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 282 - 283

questions.question: A mother notices a swelling in the abdomen of her 3-year-old child while bathing him. He had a history of hematuria two weeks back, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, a right–sided reniform ballotable mass was found. What investigations will you do? 1. CECT 2. PET-CT 3. 24 hour urinary VMA 4. FNAC
questions.explanation: (Suspected Wilms Tumor) Investigation Role in Diagnosis Justification CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan) First-line imaging for renal tumors Determines tumor size, extent, local invasion, and vascular involvement (e.g., renal vein or IVC thrombus). PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-CT) Staging and metastasis detection Helps assess lymph node involvement, lung, liver, and bone metastases . Also differentiates Wilms tumor vs. neuroblastoma . 24-hour urinary VMA (Vanillylmandelic Acid) Differentiates Wilms tumor from Neuroblastoma Neuroblastoma (adrenal origin) → elevated VMA levels ; Wilms tumor does not produce catecholamines. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology) Not recommended Contraindicated in Wilms tumor due to risk of tumor spillage , which can lead to peritoneal dissemination. Core biopsy may be done in unclear cases. Hence (Option C) 1, 2 and 3 is the right answer Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition) page 674- 678

questions.question: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is low grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Transurethral resection of the tumour Explanation: Transurethral resection of the tumour (TURBT) is the initial standard treatment for low-grade transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder. This procedure is performed using a cystoscope inserted through the urethra to remove the tumor from the bladder. TURBT allows for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes, as the tumor is removed and sent for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis and assess the stage and grade of the tumor. Resection with ileal conduit (Option B) is not the ideal management for low-grade transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. It is typically reserved for cases of invasive or high-grade bladder cancer that cannot be adequately treated with transurethral resection alone. Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction (Option C) may be considered particularly if the tumour is in a favourable location and can be completely excised while preserving bladder function. However, transurethral resection is generally the preferred initial treatment for most cases of low-grade bladder cancer. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (Option D) It is typically used for muscle-invasive bladder cancer or cases with a high risk of progression. Tumor Stage Tis (Carcinoma in situ) TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor) May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed Intravesical BCG Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36 Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy Up to 3 years Ta (Non-muscle invasive) TURBT Complete resection of tumor Low-risk: Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin) SI within 24 hours of TURBT Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation Intermediate-risk: Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine) Induction: 6 weekly courses Maintenance: Up to 1 year T1 (Muscle invasive) TURBT - For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking High-risk: Intravesical BCG Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks Maintenance: Up to 3 years Consider Cystectomy If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation) T2 (Muscle invasive) TURBT - May be used for tumor resection and staging Initial Treatment: Consider Cystectomy Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation) Adjuvant Therapy: Depending on response and tumor characteristics T3 (Advanced muscle invasive) Initial Treatment: Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned Adjuvant Therapy: Based on pathology and staging Neoadjuvant therapy may continue T4 (Locally advanced) Initial Treatment: Cystectomy Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered TURBT - Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned Adjuvant Therapy: Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/treatment-of-primary-non-muscle-invasive-urothelial-carcinoma-of-t he-bladder?search=bladder%20cancer&sectionRank=1&usage_type=default&anchor=H3412363&source=machi neLearning&selectedTitle=7~150&display_rank=7#H3412363

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition mentioned below?

options.A: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
options.B: It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection Explanation: The given image depicts Fournier's Gangrene , a severe, progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacterial flora. Definition Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis. Cause It is usually caused by mixed bacterial fora (Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp., Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus). (Option B) Clinical Presentation Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases: Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy. Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible oedema, pruritus. Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema. Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation. Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge. Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses. Severity ranges from localised tenderness to septic shock. Risk Factors Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states. Diagnosis Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings. Management Initial Treatment: Fluid resuscitation. Broad-spectrum antibiotics. Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. Additional Measures: Urinary

questions.question: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Putty kidney Explanation: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, the finding shown in the image is likely Putty kidney, a late stage of Genitourinary Tuberculosis (GUTB) , characterised by widespread calcification of non-functioning renal tissue, resulting in kidney failure. Bladder TB: Infection Progression: The infection spreads from the ureter into the bladder, with an early sign observable during cystoscopy being pallor around the ureteric orifice in the bladder. Chronic Inflammation: This inflammation leads to the formation of tubercles in the bladder, followed by fibrosis. Bladder Changes: The fibrosis results in a small, contracted bladder with significantly reduced capacity, often referred to as a "thimble bladder." Advanced TB: In advanced cases, where the bladder is contracted, the ureteric orifices may appear as "golf hole" shapes. GUTB involving the prostate: Calcification: The affected area becomes calcified, resulting in a hard and nodular texture. Testis: The testis is usually spared in cases of genitourinary tuberculosis. Characteristic Feature: A distinctive feature of tuberculosis is the "beaded" appearance of the vas deferens, often accompanied by multiple discharging sinuses through the scrotum. Investigations: Urine routine and microscopy-pyuria with or without hematuria Urine culture-sterile pyuria IVU clearly shows the effects of GUTB on the urinary tract, such as: The fuzzy or moth-eaten appearance of the calyces due to ulceration. (Earliest sign of renal TB) Strictures in the ureters cause narrowing or blockage. Hydronephrosis A small, shrunken bladder ("thimble bladder") due to fibrosis Gold standard for early genitourinary tuberculosis CECT Retrograde pyelograms (RGP)-visualisation of ureteral abnormalities and strictures Treatment: Antituberculous Therapy (ATT) : The primary treatment for GUTB is a

questions.question: A 75-year-old man with prostate carcinoma presents to you with a PSA of 9 ng/mL with a small tumour focus. His Gleason score is 6. What will be your most likely management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Active surveillance Explanation: Active surveillance is the recommended management for a patient with prostate carcinoma presenting with a PSA of 9 ng/mL, a small tumour focus, and a Gleason Score of 6. Purpose: Predicts cancer aggressiveness and potential for spread. Important for prognosis and treatment planning. Scoring System: Ranges from 6 to 10, based on gland appearance and differentiation. Two most common patterns in the biopsy are graded and summed for the final score. Gleason Score Grade Components Cancer Grade Description 6 3 + 3 Low-grade Cells resemble healthy tissue; low likelihood of growth and spread. 7 3 + 4 or 4 + 3 Intermediate-grade Cells show more variation and moderate risk of growth and spread. 8 4 + 4, 3 + 5, or 5 + 3 High-grade Cells look very different; higher likelihood of rapid growth and spread. 9 or 10 4 + 5, 5 + 4, or 5 + 5 Very high-grade Cells are highly aggressive and very likely to grow and spread quickly. CA Prostate Management: Management Strategy Key Points Active Surveillance (Option D) For low-risk cases, regular monitoring Radical Prostatectomy (Option A ruled out) Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative Radiation Therapy (Option B, C ruled out) High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy Hormone Therapy Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases Chemotherapy Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1451 , 1533-1536.

questions.question: A patient arrives after being involved in a motorcycle road traffic accident. The patient does not report any pain or injury. Upon examination, there is evidence of blood at the urethral meatus. What would be your subsequent course of action in terms of managing this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wait and watch Explanation: Blood at the tip of the urethral meatus suggests a posterior Urethral Injury , for which suprapubic cystostomy is a definitive treatment, but the initial management is conservative unless there are symptoms of urinary retention or significant pelvic hematoma. It refers to damage to the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body. Feature Anterior Urethral Injury Posterior Urethral Injury Location Bulbar urethra (most common) Penile urethra Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common) Prostatic urethra Common Causes Straddle injuries Direct trauma Iatrogenic injuries (catheterisation, cystoscopy) Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds) Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents) Blunt trauma Clinical Features Hematuria Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma) Perineal pain Urinary retention or difficulty voiding Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma Blood at the meatus Inability to void High-riding prostate on rectal exam Perineal or suprapubic pain Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures Possible concomitant bladder injury Investigations Retrograde Urethrography (RGU) : Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance. Management Minor Injuries: Managed conservatively with catheterisation or suprapubic catheter if severe bruising Severe Injuries: Surgical intervention like primary repair, urethroplasty, or end-to-end anastomosis Antibiotics: To prevent infection Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterization for urinary diversion Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management Complications Urethral stricture (risk of recurrence) Erectile dysfunction (especially if injury near the penile base) Urinary incontinence (less common) Infection (urethritis or abscess formation) Bladder neck contracture Chronic pelvic syndrome Foley’s catheterization (Option A) insertion is avoided in the presence of blood at the urethral meatus, as it may worsen a posterior urethral injury and should be delayed until imaging confirms urethral integrity. Nephrogram (Option C) is not the immediate step for managing urethral injury. Imaging, like a retrograde urethrogram, is important, but the initial evaluation should be followed to stabilise the patient and ensure proper drainage without causing further harm. Suprapubic Cystoscopy (Option D) is for significant urethral injury, retention, or obstruction, but if the injury is mild or unconfirmed, a conservative wait-and-watch approach is preferred to avoid

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a girl who has experienced continuous urinary dribbling and persistent bladder fullness since birth?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ectopic ureter Explanation: Continuous urinary dribbling and persistent bladder fullness since birth are classic symptoms of an ectopic ureter. Ectopic ureter Etiology It results from abnormal embryological development, often associated with ureteral duplication. Pathology Ectopic ureters drain to sites other than the bladder, which is commonly associated with duplication of the ureter. Pathophysiology In females, ectopic ureters open below the urethral sphincter or into the vagina, leading to incontinence . In males, ectopic ureters usually open above the external urethral sphincter, maintaining continence. Types Bilateral ectopic ureters (10% of cases). Unilateral ectopic ureters. Clinical Features Females: Continuous urinary incontinence despite normal voiding. Males: Typically asymptomatic or continent due to ureter opening above the sphincter. Diagnosis Computed Tomo-Urography (CTU). Magnetic Resonance Urography (MRU). Lab Investigations Primarily imaging-based diagnostics (CTU or MRU). Complications Persistent incontinence in females. Potential recurrent urinary tract infections. Differential Diagnosis Vesicoureteral Reflux Urethral Stricture: Difficulty in urination and weak stream, not continuous incontinence. Neurogenic Bladder Treatment Surgical correction: Reposition it into the bladder to restore normal continence. Stress incontinence (Option A) is the involuntary leakage of urine that occurs when there is increased pressure on the bladder, such as during coughing, sneezing, or exercise. It is more common in adults, especially in women, after childbirth or menopause. Ureterocele (Option B) is the congenital dilation of the distal ureter, which forms a cyst-like structure in the bladder wall. This can obstruct urine flow , potentially causing hydronephrosis or recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Vesicovaginal fistula (Option D) is an abnormal communication between the bladder and vagina, typically caused by prolonged obstructed labour. This leads to tissue breakdown and formation of a fistula, resulting in continuous leakage of urine through the vagina. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, page 1467

questions.question: Identify the investigation and the lesion depicted in the image given below:

options.A: Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture
options.B: Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture
options.D: Micturating cystourethrography with prostatic urethra stricture

questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Retrograde cystourethrogram with penile urethral stricture Retrograde cystourethrogram (RUG) is a contrast imaging technique used to assess the urethra in the context of suspected strictures or other abnormalities. The image described here is consistent with urethral stricture , where the stricture is located in the penile portion of the urethra. (Option A ruled out) Urethral Stricture Definition Abnormal narrowing of the urethra causes partial or complete obstruction of urine flow, leading to discomfort and severe complications if untreated. Causes Trauma (Most common): Pelvic fractures, falls, accidents, or iatrogenic trauma from prolonged catheterization. Infections: STIs like gonorrhoea and chlamydia cause urethritis. Medical Procedures : Urethral surgeries or radiation for pelvic cancers. Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation from conditions like lichen sclerosus. Investigations Posterior Urethral Stricture: Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) to visualize the posterior urethra and bladder during voiding. (Option C & D ruled out) Anterior Urethral Stricture: Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU). Emergency Evaluation: Both RGU and MCU may be used in trauma cases or acute urinary retention. Management Urethral Dilation: Temporary relief with dilators, often leading to recurrence. Optical Internal Urethrotomy (OIU): Endoscopic incision at the 12 o'clock position; effective for short bulbar strictures (<2 cm). Urethroplasty: Surgical excision and reconstruction; the gold standard for recurrent or complex strictures Strictures up to 2 cm: Excision with end-to-end anastomosis. Strictures >2 cm: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa, bladder mucosa, or penile skin. Retrograde cystourethrogram with membranous urethra stricture (Option A): Membranous urethral strictures are located in the part of the urethra that passes through the pelvic floor. While RUG can identify strictures in this area, the presentation described in the options fits a more distal site.

questions.question: A male patient was brought to the emergency department following a fall into a manhole, resulting in injury to his perineum. He experiences a strong urge to urinate but is unable to do so. During examination, blood is observed at the opening of the urethra, and there is swelling of the penis and scrotum. Which specific area is affected by the injury?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Bulbar urethra injury Bulbar urethra injury occurs due to trauma to the perineum, especially in cases like falls onto the perineum (e.g., falling into a manhole). The bulbar urethra is the part of the urethra that passes through the perineum, and it is the most commonly injured part in pelvic fractures. Blood at the urethral meatus, along with swelling of the scrotum and penis, points toward this injury. Feature Anterior Urethral Injury Location Bulbar urethra (most common) Penile urethra Common Causes Straddle injuries Direct trauma Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy) Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds) Clinical Features Hematuria (blood in urine) Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma) Perineal pain Urinary retention or difficulty voiding Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma Investigations Retrograde Urethrography (RGU) : Gold standard , shows the extent and location of injury Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries Membranous urethra rupture (Option A) is usually identified by a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination and difficulty voiding. However, the presence of blood at the urethral meatus and swelling of the penis and scrotum, in this case, points to a more distal injury, making membranous rupture unlikely. Prostatic urethra (Option C) injury is uncommon and usually results from high-energy trauma, often involving significant pelvic fractures. The symptoms would be less likely to involve external swelling and blood at the meatus, which suggests of a distal injury. Urinary bladder rupture (Option D) presents with abdominal pain, tenderness, hematuria and inability to pass urine. Blood at the urethral meatus and swelling of the external genitalia are not typical findings for bladder rupture.

questions.question: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with a tumour less than 4 cm in size?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Partial nephrectomy For renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with a tumour size of less than 4 cm, the treatment of choice is partial nephrectomy. This approach preserves kidney function while removing the tumour, making it the preferred method for small tumours. Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant (Option B & D ruled out) Surgical Management: Partial Nephrectomy (Option A): Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney. Indications: T1 Disease(<7cm) Restricted to poles RCC in solitary functioning kidney Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim. Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible (Option C ruled out) Ablative Techniques Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation involve destroying the tumour using extreme temperatures. Indications: Patients who are not surgical candidates Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm). Systemic Therapy (For advanced/ metastatic disease) Targeted Therapy Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib) mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus) Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab) Reference: Sabiston, Text Book of Surgery, 21st Edition, Pages 2091, 2092.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presented to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of increasing urinary frequency without burning and nocturia four times each day. He has limited his fluid consumption and caffeine intake in the evening without much benefit. On prostate examination, the swelling was palpated with a smooth surface, and a firm, non-tender rubber-like consistency was found. The physician thinks of benign prostate hypertrophy. All are characteristic features of benign prostate hypertrophy except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Increased trabeculations in the bladder Explanation: Increased trabeculations in the bladder are not characteristic features of BPH. Trabeculations refer to irregular muscular bands or folds in the bladder wall, commonly seen in conditions of chronic bladder outlet obstruction , where the bladder muscle hypertrophies due to long-term pressure, but increased trabeculations in the bladder is not commonly seen. Benign Prostate Hyperplasia (BPH) Explanation Age affected: Men over 50 years After 60 years, 50% of men have histological evidence of BPH. Common cause of significant lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men: BPH Common cause of bladder outflow obstruction (BOO) in men more than 70 years of age: BPH Etiopathogenesis Role of hormones in BPH: DHT (Dihydrotestosterone) DHT, derived from testosterone via 5-alpha reductase, binds to androgen receptors in the prostate, promoting cellular proliferation and contributing to prostatic enlargement. Estrogen Estrogen levels increase relative to testosterone in ageing men, influencing prostate growth through the activation of estrogen receptors, particularly ER- α , in the prostatic tissue. Affects both glandular epithelium and connective tissue stroma to variable degrees. Common site of origin Submucosal glands of the periurethral transitional zone Secondary changes in the bladder It is due to increased force of contraction of detrusor muscles): Collagen deposition Detrusor muscle hyperplasia Detrusor muscle hypertrophy. Clinical features Obstructive symptoms: Poor flow/stream Hesitancy Intermittency Incomplete voiding-High post-void residual urine Dribbling of urine Irritative symptoms: Frequency Urgency Nocturia Complications Retention Haematuria Urinary infection Stone formation Hydronephrosis J-shaped/ fish hook proximal ureter (Option B) is a common finding in cases of bladder outlet obstruction, where the increased pressure causes changes in the course of the ureter. J-shaped/ fish hook distal ureters (Option C) is another manifestation of the pressure changes from bladder outlet obstruction, leading to tortuosity or a hook-like appearance in the distal ureters in BPH. Bilateral hydronephrosis (Option D) II refers to the dilatation or swelling of the kidneys caused by the blockage of urine flow from the bladder. BPH can result in bladder outlet obstruction, which leads to urine backing up into the kidneys, ultimately causing hydronephrosis. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1522, 1523, SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 1033, 1034, NIH Link .

questions.question: A 68-year-old man presents to OPD with a low backache. His PSA level is 100 ng/ml. Which of the following drugs is indicated for treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Goserelin Explanation: The given condition with low back pain and an elevated PSA level of 100 ng/ml is suggestive of prostate cancer , and Goserelin is the correct drug for this patient. Goserelin is a hormonal therapy medication that is a GnRH agonist that works by reducing the levels of testosterone in the body and can help in slowing down the growth of prostate cancer cells. Prostate cancer is testosterone-dependent , and reducing testosterone levels is a critical part of managing advanced or metastatic prostate cancer. CA Prostate Management Strategy Key Points Active Surveillance For low-risk cases; regular monitoring Radical Prostatectomy Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative Radiation Therapy High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy Hormone Therapy Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases Chemotherapy Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases Somatostatin (Option A) analogues such as octreotide and lanreotide are used in treating conditions like acromegaly , carcinoid tumours , and neuroendocrine tumours , but they are not effective for treating prostate cancer . Terlipressin (Option B) is a synthetic analogue of vasopressin and is primarily used for the management of variceal bleeding (e.g., in cirrhosis with portal hypertension) but is not used in prostate cancer treatment. Testosterone (Option D) is the hormone that is often implicated in the growth of prostate cancer. Administering testosterone would exacerbate prostate cancer nand ot help in treating it. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1451 , 1533, 1534, 1535, 1536

questions.question: A 25-year-old morbidly obese male patient presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals, and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) Explanation: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the most suitable option for a 2.5 cm cystine stone (given in the image), especially in a morbidly obese patient where ESWL and ureteroscopy may be less effective. The given image shows hexagonal-shaped crystals that suggest cystine stones , typical of cystinuria . PCNL involves the creation of a small percutaneous tract through the skin, directly accessing the renal collecting system and is indicated for the treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter or stones resistant to ESWL. Typically, this procedure is done in the prone position. Fluoroscopy or ultrasound is used for localisation. The posterolateral calyx is

questions.question: According to Weigert Meyer’s rule of duplication of the ureter, the lower pole ureter in the urinary bladder is:

options.A: Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
options.B: Lateral and caudal to the upper pole ureter
options.C: Medial and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
options.D: Medial and caudal to the upper pole ureter

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter Explanation: Weigert Meyer's rule states that in incomplete duplication of the ureter, the upper pole ureter is caudal and medial compared to the lower pole ureter. Hence, the statement “lower pole ureter is positioned laterally and cephalad in relation to the upper pole ureter” corresponds with the expected anatomical configuration as per Weigert Meyer's rule. Weigert Meyer's rule explanation: The upper and lower renal moieties each have separate ureters, each with its own orifice in the bladder. The upper renal moiety ureter typically inserts ectopically, medially and inferior to the lower renal moiety ureter, often leading to a ureterocele. The lower renal moiety ureter inserts orthotopically , laterally, and superiorly to the upper moiety's ureter, which has a risk of vesicoureteral reflux. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 278,1469.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man suffered a blow on a distended bladder ,following which he developed sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium associated with syncope. Later on, as the pain subsided, the abdomen began to distend. However, he had no desire to micturate. Which among the following is true regarding his condition?

options.A: This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture
options.B: MRI is the ideal investigation to diagnose bladder rupture
options.C: Repair is done by suturing edges with single-layer 2/0 absorbable suture
options.D: Laparoscopic method is avoided as it can be done only on laparotomy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) This is a typical case of extraperitoneal bladder rupture Explanation: The patient experienced a blow to the distended bladder, resulting in sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium associated with syncope and subsequently, the abdomen began to distend, indicating leakage of urine into the extraperitoneal space. These findings are consistent with extraperitoneal bladder rupture, which occurs when the bladder wall is disrupted but the peritoneal lining remains intact. Extra peritoneal bladder rupture Definition It occurs when the bladder wall is disrupted, but the peritoneal lining remains intact, often due to trauma. Investigations (Option B ruled out) CT cystography reveals characteristic features like a flame-shaped appearance, pear sign & teardrop appearance. Retrograde cystography is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing bladder ruptures, including extraperitoneal injuries. Extravasation of contrast limited to the perivesical space is a key finding that helps differentiate extraperitoneal from intraperitoneal ruptures, where contrast would outline bowel loops. Management Initial management: Urethral catheterisation with free bladder drainage for 10-14 days. Followed by a cystogram to confirm healing before catheter removal. If the injury is iatrogenic: Repair during the same procedure (open or laparoscopic). Repair done in two layers using 2/0 vicryl absorbable sutures (Option C ruled out) Bladder injury with pelvic fracture: The bladder should be repaired at the same time during the surgery for pelvic fracture. Immediate surgical repair is indeed indicated in cases where there are complicating factors like intravesical bone spicules, bladder neck injuries , or associated vaginal or rectal lacerations. Laparoscopy can be used in the management of bladder rupture, particularly in cases where less invasive approaches are preferred (Option D ruled out) .

questions.question: An 11-month-old boy had a recent urinary tract infection that was resolved with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination revealed an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. However, a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. The USG revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal, as shown in the image below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Surgical exploration Explanation: The condition described in the question is most likely cryptorchidism , where the testicle fails to descend into the scrotum, and as the testis is located in a suboptimal location like the inguinal canal (as seen in the ultrasound), surgical exploration is typically the next step in management. Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism) Definition It is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen. Locations Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80% Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20% Diagnosis Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration. (Option D) Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy. (Option B ruled out) Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilised to locate the testis. Treatment Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old. (Option C ruled out) Types of Orchidopexy Ombridannes Keetley-Torek Stephen-Fowler Ladd & Gross Observation (Option A) is not the best option since the child is approaching the age when early intervention is critical for testicular health. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1559 -1561. SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 1065 - 1068.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with a low backache and weight loss. He has progressive difficulty in urination and had an episode of urinary retention two days back, which was relieved by catheterisation. PSA was done, which was 5.2 ng/ml, and an x-ray of the LS spine showed osteoblastic changes. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Prostate cancer Explanation: The combination of urinary symptoms , elevated PSA , and osteoblastic changes on the x-ray strongly points to prostate cancer. Osteoblastic changes in the lumbar spine are a characteristic feature that suggests bone metastasis, which is common in prostate cancer, as it frequently metastasises to bone. Investigations for Prostate Cancer DRE Physical examination detects nodules but is limited in early-stage PSA Test Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer TRUS Imaging with the rectal probe detects abnormalities mpMRI Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread Prostate Biopsy The gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells Benign prostatic hypertrophy (Option A) can also cause urinary symptoms like difficulty urinating and urinary retention , but it does not cause weight loss or osteoblastic bone changes on an x-ray. Additionally, the PSA in BPH is usually mildly elevated but not to the degree seen in prostate cancer. Carcinoma bladder (Option B) can cause urinary symptoms like hematuria, dysuria, or obstructive voiding symptoms, but it is less likely to cause osteoblastic changes in the bones, and the PSA elevation is also not characteristic of bladder cancer. Renal cell cancer (Option D) presents with symptoms such as hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable abdominal mass. The symptoms described by the patient, along with the elevated PSA level and osteoblastic changes on the X-ray, are not characteristic of renal cell cancer. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1451 , 1533-1536

questions.question: What should be the initial course of action for a patient who has presented with a pelvic fracture and a rupture in the membranous urethra?

options.A: A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible. Explanation: The initial course of action for a patient with a pelvic fracture and ruptured membranous urethra is to insert a suprapubic catheter for urinary diversion. By placing a suprapubic catheter, urine can be diverted from the injured urethra, ensuring proper bladder drainage. This helps prevent urinary retention, minimises the risk of urinary extravasation, and reduces further damage to the urethra. Suprapubic catheterisation is considered a temporary solution to manage urine drainage until definitive treatment, such as urethral repair, can be performed. Membranous urethral rupture is a type of Posterior Urethral Injury. The posterior urethra consists of the prostatic urethra and membranous urethra , and injuries in this region are often caused by pelvic fractures , particularly from high-energy trauma like motor vehicle accidents. Investigations, Management & Complications of Posterior Urethral Injuries Investigations Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment CT Urethrography : Useful in evaluating complex injuries Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance Management Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterisation for urinary diversion Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided (Option B ruled out) Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management Complications Urethral stricture (most common long-term complication) Urinary incontinence (due to sphincter damage) Erectile dysfunction (common due to injury near neurovascular structures) Bladder neck contracture Chronic pelvic syndrome IVP (Option B) can be useful for evaluating the urinary tract, but it is not the initial step in the management of a ruptured urethra . The patient should be stabilised first, with urinary diversion (via suprapubic catheter), before any imaging studies are done. MCU should be done (Option D): Micturating Cystourethrogram is an imaging study that evaluates the urethra and bladder during voiding. While it may be helpful in assessing the extent of a urethral injury, it is not the first step in management. The priority is to manage the patient's urinary diversion and stabilise them before any imaging studies are performed. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1541,1542, SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 1040-1042

questions.question: What is the cause of the following appearance in IVP?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ureterocoele Explanation: The cobra head appearance in IVP is most characteristic of ureterocoele , where there is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter at its insertion into the bladder. Ureterocele is the congenital dilation of the distal ureter within the bladder wall. It can obstruct urine flow, leading to recurrent UTIs and hydronephrosis. Treatment often involves surgical correction to relieve the obstruction. Ureterocoele Types Simple Ureterocele (Intravesical - 20%): Found entirely within the bladder and associated with a single ureter. It is less complex and easier to manage. Ectopic Ureterocele (80%) : Extends beyond the bladder and often involves a duplicated ureter. This is more complicated due to its location, which may involve the bladder, neck, or urethra. Etiology Congenital anomaly is caused by an obstruction in the development of the distal ureter during fetal growth, leading to cystic dilation at the ureteral orifice. Clinical Features Recurrent Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)/ Urosepsis. Unilateral Hydroureteronephrosis. Palpable Abdominal Mass: Particularly in children, where a distended bladder or large ureterocele might be felt as a mass. Investigations Ultrasound (USG):

questions.question: A 30-year-old man developed abdominal pain for which he was being evaluated. You notice the following in his CECT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Horseshoe kidney Explanation: The most likely condition, based on the provided options and typical CT findings, is Horseshoe kidney . It is a congenital anomaly where the two kidneys are fused at their lower poles, forming a “U” or "horseshoe" shape. Horseshoe kidney Causes During fetal development, the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure. This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen. Clinical features Mostly asymptomatic. Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones. Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Hydronephrosis. Hematuria Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain. Investigations CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualisation of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications. Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include : Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the " Hand Joining Sign." High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters. Treatment Treatment depends on the presence and severity of symptoms: Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment but should be monitored periodically. Symptomatic Patients: UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent. Isthmus Management: The

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who visited the outpatient department (OPD) experiencing intense pain during erection and a deviated penis for the past half-year?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Peyronie’s disease Explanation: The patient described in the scenario, experiencing intense pain during erection and a deviated penis for the past six months, is most likely suffering from Peyronie’s disease . Peyronie’s disease Definition It is characterised by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea of the penis, causing abnormal curvature during erections. Characteristics Plaque Location: Typically on the dorsolateral aspect of the penis. Curvature: Resulting from plaque contraction. Causes Trauma/Injury: Repeated minor trauma to the penis. Genetic Factors: Possible genetic predisposition. Connective Tissue Disorders: Associated with conditions like Dupuytren’s contracture. Associated Conditions Galezia’s Triad: Dupuytren’s Contracture: Thickening and shortening of connective tissue in fingers. Retroperitoneal Fibrosis: Fibrosis in the retroperitoneal space. Peyronie’s Disease Clinical Features Painful Erection Erectile Dysfunction Penile Curvature Palpable Plaques Impotence & Infertility (in severe cases) Treatment Observation: Spontaneous Resolution: Often improves without treatment. Medical Management: Oral Medications: Pentoxifylline, colchicine, vitamin E (efficacy varies). Surgical Intervention (If Spontaneous Resolution Does Not Occur): Nesbit Operation: Placement of a non-absorbable suture opposite the plaque to correct the curvature. Plication Surgery: Shortens the longer side of the penis. Plaque Excision and Grafting: Removes plaque and replaces it with graft material. Penile Prosthesis: For severe cases. Priapism (Option B) is a condition where a prolonged and often painful erection occurs unrelated to sexual stimulation. It is typically unrelated to penile curvature and is caused by abnormal blood flow in the penis, leading to stagnant blood in the erectile tissues. It is considered a urological emergency and requires immediate medical attention. Marion’s disease (Option C) is also known as bladder neck stenosis or primary bladder neck obstruction (PBNO). Marion described diseases affecting the bladder and neck as causing urinary disturbances resembling those caused by prostate enlargement. However, these disturbances result from changes in the bladder neck itself, without any visible abnormalities. Erectile dysfunction (Option D) is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual intercourse. It is not associated with pain or penile curvature. In some cases, pain or discomfort may accompany an erection, but it is not the primary symptom of ED.

questions.question: What is the diagnosis based on the X-ray given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bladder calculi Explanation: The X-ray image shows radio-opaque shadows within the pelvis, which are consistent with bladder calculi. Bladder stones can be classified into primary and secondary types based on their underlying causes. Type Primary Bladder Stones Secondary Bladder Stones Causes Nutritional deficiency (Vitamins A, B6, magnesium, protein-carbohydrate imbalance) Bladder outlet obstruction, infection, foreign body presence Common Composition Ammonium urate, calcium oxalate Uric acid, struvite (infection-related) Common Population Children in developing countries Adults with urinary tract dysfunction or infection Clinical Presentation May be asymptomatic or present with dysuria, hematuria Hematuria, dysuria, frequency and urgency, Investigations A simple X-ray, renal tract ultrasound or CT scan Renal calculi (Option A) are typically found in the renal pelvis or kidney . Though they can cause similar symptoms, they are located in the upper urinary tract so that they would be seen above the bladder, not within it. Schistosomiasis (Option C) is a parasitic infection caused by Schistosoma species, which can affect the bladder and cause hematuria , bladder

questions.question: A 60-year-old patient undergoes TURP, and after 3 days, the patient develops altered sensitiveness and drowsiness. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hyponatremia Explanation: The patient is experiencing altered sensitivity and drowsiness 3 days after undergoing TURP (Transurethral Resection of the Prostate) , raising suspicion for hyponatremia as the most likely diagnosis. TURP Syndrome is a complication that can occur after a TURP procedure, which results from excessive absorption of irrigating fluids during the surgery, leading to hyponatremia , fluid overload , and a variety of systemic symptoms. TURP Syndrome Pathophysiology It is because fluid is absorbed intravascularly due to high volumes of hypotonic irrigation fluid used during the resection, causing dilutional hyponatremia and various neurologic symptoms. Risk factors Size of prostate > 75g Duration of surgery > 90 minutes Pre-existing hyponatremia Renal failure Clinical presentation Confusion, Agitation, Nervousness, Nausea, Hemolysis, Visual disturbances, Coma and shock. Treatment Drug of choice: IV furosemide. Mild to moderate cases: IV furosemide and normal saline Severe or symptomatic patients: IV 3% Saline Fluid restriction: Useful after initial stabilisation and correction of severe hyponatremia to prevent further fluid overload. Hypernatremia (Option A) symptoms include thirst , muscle twitching , muscle weakness, seizures and confusion . It is less likely in this case since the patient is experiencing drowsiness , which is more characteristic of hyponatremia . Stroke (Option C) can present with altered consciousness or neurological deficits such as hemiparesis or aphasia . However, stroke symptoms typically present suddenly and are not typically related to a postoperative time frame of 3 days. The timing of the symptoms makes a stroke less likely unless there is a specific underlying vascular issue. Hyponatremia is a more common cause of these symptoms after TURP. Meningitis due to spinal anaesthesia (Option D) is a rare complication, with symptoms including fever , headache , neck stiffness, nausea, vomiting and photophobia . The timing of the symptoms (3 days after surgery) is not typical for spinal meningitis . Also, the given symptoms align more with hyponatremia . Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1530

questions.question: What is the recommended initial investigation for genital tuberculosis?

options.B: Urine sample for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) culture
options.C: Genital swab for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing

questions.explanation: options: Endometrial biopsy: While endometrial biopsy can be useful in diagnosing genital TB, it is an invasive procedure and may not be the first-line investigation. Endometrial biopsy is typically considered when other less invasive tests, such as PCR testing, have not provided a conclusive diagnosis or when there is a strong clinical suspicion of genital TB. Urine sample for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) culture: Urine sample for AFB culture is essential in diagnosing genitourinary TB, but it may not be the early investigation of choice for genital TB. Genitourinary TB can involve the kidneys, bladder, and ureters, leading to the presence of mycobacteria in the urine. However, when specifically investigating for genital TB, other tests like PCR are more targeted and less invasive. Genital swab for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing: This is the correct option. PCR testing is a sensitive and specific method to detect the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA in genital samples. PCR testing allows for the rapid identification of TB infection in the genital tract and can be an early investigation of choice. It is less invasive compared to procedures like endometrial biopsy and provides a targeted approach to diagnosing genital TB. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray is useful for diagnosing pulmonary TB (TB affecting the lungs), it may not be the primary investigation for genital TB. Genital TB is a specific form of extrapulmonary TB, and although pulmonary TB can be associated with genital TB, direct investigation of the genital tract is needed for a definitive diagnosis. Endometrial biopsy involves obtaining a tissue sample from the lining of the uterus (endometrium) for pathological examination. In cases of suspected genital TB, endometrial biopsy can reveal granulomatous inflammation, caseating necrosis, or acid-fast bacilli, which are indicative of TB infection. It provides direct evidence of TB involvement in the genital tract. Reference: .

questions.question: 62 year old female has kidney stone and treated with PCNL. After 2 days she again comes to OPD with chills and fever. What is the complication?
questions.explanation: like PCNL, bacterial sepsis is a significant concern. It could result from the introduction of bacteria during the procedure, leading to systemic infection. Incorrect Options: Option A - Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis is not a common complication of PCNL. It involves inflammation of the pancreas and is usually not directly related to the procedure. Option B - Splenic injury: Splenic injury is not a typical complication of PCNL.
